news uk-news harry-meghans-betrayal-royals-more-"Meghan Markle says it is wonderful to be back in New YorkByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Nov | commentsPrince Harry and Meghan Markleaposs absence from the royal family is more signicant than ever while the Queen is resting, a former royal butler has said. The monarch is currently taking it easy after cancelling all working visits until mid-November and has been advised to stick to “light, desk-based duties”. Several of her royal engagements have been cancelled and it was revealed that she wonapost be attending the annual Festival of Remembrance at the Royal Albert Hall on November . The Queen, who has recently used a walking stick for the first time on royal visits, is recovering after she had tests and spent a night in hospital last month. Meanwhile, Harry and Meghan are living in Calornia with their two children Archie and Lilibet after deciding to quit as senior royals last year. And former royal butler Paul Burrell, who worked for both the Queen and Princess Diana, says Harry and Meghan could have been an incredible help to the Firm at this time.He told Closer magazine : We’ve seen recently that her [the Queenaposs] family have rallied around her to support her and take on more. Kate and William have been thriving – and their work will be a huge support and relief to the Queen. And we’ve seen other members of the family step up to take on more engagements in recent weeks, too. Harry and Meghan’s absence from ‘the firm’ is more signicant than ever.Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. Their betrayal of the royals is more noticeable now than ever. With everyone stepping up to support the Queen, Harry and Meghan would have been an incredible help, but they’re not – they’re in America. They should be here right now, supporting his elderly grandmother. “I’d find it unfathomablenews of the Queen’s hospital admission wouldn’t have hit Harry and Meghan hard. It must have made them both realise what they’ve done, how far away they are, and the dilemma they are faced with – they are not only denying themselves time with her but denying their children, Archie and Lilibet, time with their great-grandmother.” Despite stepping down from royal duties, Harry and Meghan have continued to make public appearances. In September they held a series of meetings in New York City with the likes of Big Apple mayor Bill de Blasio and visited a school in Harlem.And next week is also shaping up to be a busy one for the Sussexes. On Tuesday, Meghan will speak at an event hosted by the New York Times on economic and professional parity for women. On the same day, Harry will take part in a virtual discussion on tackling the internet lie machine, hosted by Wired magazine. The summit organisers said: The Duke of Sussex joins misinformation experts for a session titled The Internet Lie Machine, which will examine what the real cost of a lie on the internet is – to ourselves, our communities, and our societies. On Wednesday, he will also attend the Salute to Freedom gala to present the inaugural Intrepid Valour Awards to service personnel, veterans and their families. The ceremony takes place at the Intrepid Sea, Air  Space Museum in New York City. title: incredible images show pro gamer
story: Incredible images show pro-gamer with ft " long pizza - and its the same size as himTwitch user Luke Dutch quickly met the target gaining more than , likes for his screenshot of the conversation exchange with Pizza Hut which led to the firm creating the vast pizzaLuke Dutch posted a hilarious photograph of him and his pizza laying side-by-side on the floorByDarren McConachieGraeme Murray:,  Nov Incredible images show a pro-gamer beside a ft  long pizza - that is the same height as him.Luke Dutch challenged Pizza Hut in July to make him a pizza that was as tall as himhe was able to get , retweets of the request on Twitter.The -year-old Twitch streamer quickly smashed through the target gaining over , likes for his screenshot of the conversation exchange with Pizza Hut. Sticking to their deal, a Pizza Hut delivery driver arrived at Lukeaposs house on Tuesdaywith the impressive ft  pizza. Luke, from Liverpool, was delighted when he was handed over the huge meal which had to be placed inside a custom made pizza box.  Pizza Hut took photographs of each step they took to cook the pizza, from making the base to feeding it into the pizza oven. Luke posted a hilarious photograph of him and his pizza laying side-by-side on the floor on Twitter on Tuesday captioned: The beauty of the internet. The post has gained over , likes and almost  retweets. Dozens of impressed followers left comments after being impressed by Pizza Hut sticking to their end of the bargain.@Beaney said: Hope there was plenty of garlic mayo dip for that bad boy.  @Frankleachwhu wrote: And not a piece of pineapple in sight. Good lad. @tigermac said: Holy mother of God. @JedLB commented: Box doubles up as the coffin youaposll need after consuming it. And @Chivs added: Will need to get the whole street in to help him finish it after he hammers down his fourth slice.  The Liverpudlian live-streamed himself attempting to eat the pizza while gaming on his Twitch page shortly after. The iety of toppings included pepperoni, mushroom and ham, beef and peppers. By the end of Lukeaposs video there was at least half of the pizza still left. news uk-news mini-ant-dec-pride-britain-"Pride of Britain: Carol Vorderman praises incredible winnersByClaire OBoyle:,  Nov | commentsThereaposs nothing like having your best pal by your side to make you feel you can conquer the world – as Ant and Dec were reminded when they met two young heroes who could be set to take over the Geordie duo as the nation’s favourite friends.After raising more than £, for charity, Hughie Higginson, , and Freddie Xavi, , melted hearts when they promised to be pals forever at this year’s Pride of Britain Awards.At the star-studded event, to be aired on ITV on Thursday night in partnership with TSB, leukaemia sufferer Hughie said: “The bond between us is unbreakable, we’ll be friends forever.” Freddie, who ran km a day for  days to support him, added: “He’s my best friend for le. We’re basically brothers.” Have your say on this story in the comment section  Their inspirational journey began last year when Hughie was diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukaemia. He began three and a half years of treatment and was determined to thank doctors and nurses caring for him at the Royal Manchester Children’s Hospital. He signed up for a fundraising walk but was too ill on the day to join in. It was then that Freddie got involved, going on to complete his running challenge on Christmas Day with Hughie gathering all his strength to join him so they could cross the finish line together.  Freddie laughed: “People do call us the mini Ant and Dec.” And in the first surprise of many, on a day when the youngsters thought they’d been invited to the I’m A Celebrity Jungle Challenge in Manchester as a reward for their hard work, the TV presenters sneaked out of the show’s famous red phone box. Dec said: “What they don’t know, is that we’re here.” Ant added: “And we’ve got a few surprises up our sleeves for so-called ‘Little Ant and Dec’.”  As Hughie and Freddie got stuck in to the jungle challenge, the two stars waited to surprise the pair with news they were to be named Good Morning Britain’s Young Fundraisers of the Year. Ant said: “We know what it’s like when a best mate helps out another best mate.” He and Dec crowned them honorary Princes of the Jungle before challenging them to try out their Geordie accents. Hughie joked: “Aw, what a great day we’ve had, man,” said Hughie.” Freddie added: “Aye, champion”.  Introducing the award at the ceremony in London, Good Morning Britain’s Ben Shephard told the crowd: “This year’s winners are living proof that friendship conquers all.” Ben asked Hughie what it felt like to see their hard work pay off after they raised money for everything from le-saving equipment to fresh fruit and drinks for young cancer patients. The lad, from Higham, Lancs, said: “Just to see what we have done in action.” Asked what kept him running each day, Freddie, from Whalley, Lancs, added: “I knew Hughie was going through a harder time. What I was doing was nowhere near as hard.”  KSI fan Hughie sang one of the star’s hits Holiday, impressing Simon Cowell and Alesha Dixon in the crowd. Hughie was stunned when the rapper sneaked up behind him to present him with his award. KSI said: “I just want to say how proud I am of both of you.” Later Olympian Sir Mo Farah gave a second gong to the pair so they could take one home each. He said. “It’s incredible to see such courage and commitment at that age. And to do it for one of his best friends, there’s no words to really describe it.” Oxford vaxx aces jab fab A standing ovation for the Oxford Vaccine Team went on and on... and on. The scientists stood modestly on stage as they were given a Special Recognition Award. Stephen Fry, who presented it, said: “Their speed and commitment and the midnight oil that was burned. It’s incredible.”  Dr Catherine Green joked the team lived on Mini Cheddars and Bountys during -hour days. She added: “It was lovely to have the recognition of the public.” There ain’t nothing like a Dame for blast amputee From taking part in two Invictus Games and running across America, Mark Ormrod has more than defied the odds as the first triple amputee to survive an IED blast in Afghanistan.Now the former Royal Marine is a Pride of Britain winner after being named ITV ’s Fundraiser of the Year.Mark, , of Plymouth, who has raised more than half a million pounds for veterans charity Reorg, said: “It was a shock, a bit over-whelming, ultimately I’m just proud.”  Mark lost an arm and both legs below the knee in Helmand Province on Christmas Eve . Speaking after he received his award from Dame Joan Collins and Dame Sarah Storey, he said: “Two Dames, two legends, it’s amazing. “I feel like the filling in a very beautul sandwich.” Dame Joan said: “You’re fantastic, inspiring and spectacular.” Comment MORE ON Pride of Britain winnersPride of Britain AwardsITV Pride of Britain AwardsAnthony McPartlinDeclan Donnelly" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mum living toddler baby mouldy
story: Mum living with toddler and baby in mouldy home so grim shes caught  miceParaskevi Karagkouni, , lives in a one-bedroom property, provided by social landlord Clarion Housing , with her partner and their two young daughters but is appalled with the conditionsParaskevi Karagkouni says she catches  mice a day at the property Image: BPM MEDIAByRuby Gregory:,  Nov | commentsA mum-of-two said she fears for the health of her family due to toxic black mould and a rodent problem at her home which is so bad , mice have been caught.Paraskevi Karagkouni lives in a one-bedroom property, provided by controversial social landlord Clarion Housing, with her partner and their two young children.The couple moved into the one-bedroom property in Penge in  and Paraskevi has since had her -month-old daughter and gave birth to a baby girl last month. Paraskevi, , a university student originally from Athens, Greece, says she and her partner have complained repeatedly about the problems in their home and is pleading for a safer environment to raise her two children in. Clarion is responsible for repair works and Paraskevi said a few months ago handymen cleaned and painted over the black mould in the bathroom but itaposs since grown back at an alarming rate.She told MyLondon : I’m really scared for my youngest, I shower her every day but I’m really worried, after two or three minutes I take her out of the bathroom because I don’t want her breathing it in.I also have to change my face cream and toothbrushes all the time because of the issue - it’s really bad. Black mould is visible in all corners of the familyaposs bedroom and living room, which Paraskevi believes is the cause of her daughteraposs chest infection. While the family sleep at night, their bedroom becomes a playground for mice - closing doors doesnapost stop them from creating havoc in the bedroom. Paraskevi estimates over , mice have been caught inside her home, with up to three a day in traps. She believes sheaposs spent over £ on mousetraps so far and she canapost let her children play on the floor and also feels uncomfortable resting them on her bed.  She added: ‘I’m really worried about putting my kids even on the bed, for my newborn it’s quite risky. But I don’t have any other choice because of the mice. I wouldn’t mind living in this houseI had a better environment - it’s not so much about living in one bedroom, it’s about being in these conditions with my kids, Why does this happen to me  I feel really sad for my kids, they canapost play around. Paraskevi says she wonapost give up the fight for better housing for her and her family. She has written to her MP, Ellie Reeves, about the issues and last month a healthcare worker told Clarion the property is a health risk for her two young children. Paraveski explained: I’m a really hardworking person. I’m trying my best, I’m still in education and going back to work. I’m trying to do everything for my kids to have a better future for us. I donapost want to give up, I will never give up on anything in my le. A Clarion spokesperson told MyLondon: “We are aware of Ms Karagkouni’s current situation and are committed to resolving the mould problem so her family can feel more comfortable in their home.  Following a visit to assess the issue in September, our operatives were due to install a humidistat fan to the bathroom and complete mould treatments. The visit to complete the work was subsequently cancelled at the residents’ request and this has been rescheduled for next week. Our pest control contractor also visited the property in September and the follow up visit has also been rescheduled, at the residents’ request, to a more convenient time.Clarion added: “Ms Karagkouni’s family currently needs a larger home and overcrowding can contribute to increased condensation and mould growth. We will be discussing options for the household to move to a new property that better meets their needs.” Clarion, which manages , properties across the UK and is Europeaposs largest housing association, has come under fire by scores of tenants who claim they are being forced to live in horric conditions. Last week Dawn Page from Merton, south London, said her house became “uninhabitable” due to a sewage leak inside her kitchen and toilet has been forced to spend months in a hotel with her daughter. When the -year-old first reported the leak to Clarion on July , she was told it was fine to continue cooking in her kitchen, where the leak was dripping down onto surfaces and behind cupboards.  It wasnapost until the beginning of August when Dawn forwarded information from Environmental Health to Clarion, confirming it was a serious health risk, that she and her -year-old child were eventually moved into a hotel. Last month The Mirror reported that another tenant who has been living in hotels for three months might not be rehoused until Christmas after being moved out of her damp, mouldy and vermin filled home. Clarion Housing moved care worker Louise Plunkett into a hotel in July after she was hospitalised with breathing problems while living in conditions so bad she had to sleep on her sofa for nine months. The -year-old Mitcham resident had been complaining to Clarion for almost a decade, but was getting nowhere with the housing association.In May -year-old Kwajo Tweneboa, who lives on the Eastfields Estate in Mitcham, spoke about the appalling state he has been forced to live in and said that once workmen told him that not even animals would live in these conditions.He said his dad died of cancer while living at the property and claims the poor conditions contributed to his death. title: mums horror shes engulfed flames
story: Exclusive: Mum almost burnt alive as bonfire accident engulfs her in flames for  minutesWARNING GRAPHIC IMAGES: In a split second Louise Chadwicks entire lower body caught alight and the burning petrol that drenched her clothes was slowly starting to creep up her body - now shes warning others ahead of Bonfire Night Image: Louise Chadwick   SWNSByHarrison Moore:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov A woman engulfed in flames for five minutes in a freak accident has spoken of her horror ahead of Bonfire Night. Louise Chadwick suffered  severe burns on her shins, thighs, legs, feet, arms, hands and lower torso after starting a bonfire in her garden. It took over a year for her burns to heal, but the scars she has will stay with her forever, both physically and mentally. Shortly after the accident Louise was diagnosed with PTSD, which can be triggered by everyday activities including filling the car up with petrol. The horror fire while she was refurbishing her daughteraposs bedroom with her daughteraposs ex-boyfriend, and the two ripped out a wardrobe which later needed disposing of. They decided the best way was to burn it in the back garden using petrol to get the fire going. Louise, , and partner Carl Dover, , had used this method to dispose of old furniture and other waste several times before - but this time he was away with work. So, with the help of Jamie as some extra muscle, they moved the wardrobe into the garden and set it alight. But when Louise went to pour the petrol over the furniture, she didnapost know that Jamie had already got the fire going - and the entire wardrobe burst into flames. The petrol can Louise was holding immediately caught fire and she dropped it on the floor, spilling it all over the grass. Louise then slipped in the puddle of fluid and fell flat on her back, covering herself in petrol as she fell. In a split second, her entire lower body was engulfed in flames and the burning petrol that drenched her clothes was slowly starting to creep up her body.  Louise, from Radclfe, Manchester, said: At first I was in complete shock. Everything happened so fast from the moment I poured the petrol to the horror that came afterwards. My arms went up first, but things really got serious when I slipped and drenched myself in petrol fluid. Thataposs when my pajama bottoms set alight and the flames started to rise up towards my torso. I could feel the heat quickly nearing my face, but I couldnapost get my trousers off because I was wearing my partners slippers. Jamie was trying to help me get them off but he was in complete shock at what was happening. It felt like I was burning for a letime, and I genuinely thought this is how my le is going to end. After five minutes of unimaginable pain, with the help of her youngest daughter Georgia Mulbey, , Louise finally managed to put herself out. Georgia, who was upstairs at the time, came rushing down to the sound of Louiseaposs screams, and filled up several jugs of water to frantically throw over her mother.  Eventually, Louiseaposs clothes were wet enough to extinguish the flames and she was able to briefly escape the torture sheaposd just endured. However, the aftermath of the accident proved equally horric as Louise suddenly realised the severity of her burns. The mum of two suffered third degree burns all over her lower body and arms leaving her in need of a skin graft. She was airlted to hospital as a result of her injuries and spent the next two weeks in intensive care. She also has an extreme phobia of any kind of open flame - making fireworks and bonfire night a terrying occasion.  Every day that goes by I still think about what happened, Louise said. The scars on my body have healed as much as they ever will, but itaposs my mental health thataposs been damaged the most. The first time I went to fill my car up since the accident I started screaming in the middle of the petrol station - in that moment I felt so much fear. Iaposve had countless nightmares where Iaposve woken up thinking I was burning and my kids have had to come in and calm me down. Over the years, I have been terried of bonfire night and fireworks, but I have a grandson now, and I donapost want to miss out on important parts of his childhood. This year, Iaposm going to face my fears head on surrounded by my family, and speaking out about my accident is definitely a way of helping me accept whataposs happened. She said she wanted to speak out about fire safety to warn others about how easily things can go wrong and end in tragedy. Louise pleaded with people to stay safe and not take risks as bonfire night arrives and celebrations begin. I want people to realise the dangers associated with bonfires and how quickly things can go wrong.With so much changing so quickly, keep on top of what is happening with the Mirroraposs news updates by email. Delivered straight to your inbox, our daily coronavirus briefing will keep you informed of what is happening with Covid, lockdown, the vaccination rollout and the impact on how we live.here. I wouldnapost wish what happened to me upon my worst enemy and I hope everyone out there stays safe this bonfire night. In light of her accident, Louise has retrained as a hair and make-up artist, to help burn victims feel happy with their appearance. She recently gained her industry qualications with the help of her daughters, and canapost wait to see where her new career take her in the future. title: mystery lottery ticket holder urged
story: Mystery lottery ticket winner urged to come forward as £million jackpot sits unclaimedCamelot’s Andy Carter, Senior Winners’ Advisor at The National Lottery, urged Lotto players to check their tickets for “the chance to see their wealth ‘skyrocket’”The £m jackpot prize from last Saturday’s draw currently remains unclaimed Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByAlice Peacock:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments Brits are being urged to check their Lotto tickets, as the £m jackpot prize from last Saturday’s draw remains unclaimed. The hefty prize was from a ticket bought in retail, The National Lottery has said.The Lotto draw on  October saw just one lucky ticket-holder scoop the huge £,, jackpot prize. As with all prizes £, and above that are won in retail, approximately two weeks after the draw,no valid claim has been received, the area in which the ticket was purchased is released. Camelot’s Andy Carter, Senior Winners’ Advisor at The National Lottery, urged Lotto players to check their tickets for “the chance to see their wealth ‘skyrocket’”. “This could be a le-changing win for the lucky ticket-holder and we’re hoping that they will now come forward and claim their amazing prize,” he said. News of the unclaimed prize comes ahead of another big weekend in the lotto stakes - a £m Lotto ‘Must Be Won’ jackpot is up for grabs on Saturday night.  In a Lotto ‘Must Be Won’ draw, the jackpot has to be won, either by players matching all six numbers, orthe jackpot isn’t won it will filter down the prize tiers to boost all the other prizes. In this instance, lots of players could win lots more. Once a winning ticket-holder has called Camelot and the claim has been validated and paid, they then have the opportunity to decide whether or not to go public and share their news.A mother and son were both jumping for joy after winning £, each playing Peopleaposs Postcode Lottery. Sixty-year-old Kathleen Miller and son Paul, , hit the jackpot after their postcode L SQ in Bootle, Merseyside, came up trumps. People’s Postcode Lotterycosts £ a month to play and there are guaranteed winners every day. People play with their chosen postcode and are automatically entered into all draws.A minimum of % from each ticket goes to charity and players have raised more than £million for over , charities and good causes since . No information is provided on whether a National Lottery win is an inidual or syndicate win, unless the ticket-holder decides to go public.National Lottery players can check their tickets online atnational-lotteryor by downloading the National Lottery app.For those playing online via the website or app, then your ticket is automatically checked, and you get an email noticationyou win a prize. title: nine out 10 people want
story: Nine out of  people want fireworks to be banned from public saleThe results of our Bonfire Night survey with our sister site TeamDogs are in and lots of you said the same thing per cent of you voted that fireworks should be banned from public sale in our recent Bonfire Night poll with TeamDogs, our sister site for dog lovers and pet parents. Image: Mike Harrington   GettyByTilly Alexander:,  Nov | commentsThe results of our Bonfire Night poll on banning home fireworks are in – and you gave us a decisive verdict.Earlier this week, we asked you and readers of Reach Plc’s other regional and national brands, as well as our sister site TeamDogs, to have your say on whether fireworks should be banned from public sale.With an overwhelming response from over , participants, it’s clear that you feel strongly about the topic. In addition, you also made your feelings about whether fireworks should be allowed to be bought and set off by private persons very clear. Of the , who voiced their opinions, , peoplevoted that fireworks should be banned from public sale. And for many participants, this choice was linked to the impact that the unexpected bangs and flashes, often over multiple days, have on domestic pets. In fact,  per cent added that their dog is afraid of fireworks, with many sharing heart-breaking stories about the impact Bonfire Night festivities have on them.This is Toffee. Toffee is a cheeky ginger cockapoo who is friendly and full of fun - except on Bonfire Night.If you’ve ever had a shaking, terried dog in your arms on Bonfire Night, you’ll know exactly how traumatising fireworks can be.The loud bangs and unexpected flashes are enough to make us scared - let alone our precious pups who don’t understand what’s going on outside. Our sister site TeamDogs - and appeal mascot Toffee - is asking everyone to donate a tin of dog food to a local rescue centre instead of buying fireworks this year. You can find your local centre here and discover more about the #BeMoreToffee appeal here. Or print off and colour in this poster for your window, asking others to support it. One said: “I have a dog who spends the weeks before and after fireworks night quivering with fear. “I think no fireworks should be sold to the public, they are weapons.” Another added: “So many pets are scared stf of them. “My vet has now prescribed diazepam for one of my dogs because she gets in such a state.” A third person also said: “They are terrying to dogs and our Labrador literally shakes and digs at the floor because she is so scared. “She goes in kennels in the middle of nowhere on Bonfire Night and New Year so she is away from them, but we canapost put her in kennels for the full few weeks that people set them off for.” Another recurring reason for banning fireworks included the stressful impact the noise has on inidual who are more vulnerable, such as the elderly. Others also highlighted that they were ‘dangerous in the wrong hands’, and can be ‘misused to terrorise people’, particularly by ‘kids’, ‘teenagers’ or other ‘youths’. One participant added: “Some people with autism and learning disabilities find fireworks frightening due to sensory overload. “Also, for people with dementia and PTSD fireworks can provoke flashbacks.”A second also said: “Too many idiots let off fireworks at random hours with complete disregard for who it affects – other people, domesticated animals, wildle, pollution.”As for solutions to keeping up Bonfire Night celebrations, respondents were more ided, putting forward ious ideas. Some respondents, for example, suggested that standard fireworks should be licenced and only used for public Guy Fawkes Night displays, which would only be on ‘specic firework nights’. Others suggested that even public Bonfire Night celebrations should use low level noise fireworks. And while  per cent of people agreed with low noise fireworks only being sold to the public, some felt that this type should not be available for sale to private iniduals either.Find out more about the TeamDogs fireworks campaign, Toffee’s Appeal , here.Comment MORE ON New YearMental healthFireworksAnimalsDogsTeamDogsBonfire Night" data-immediate"data-immediate"Calling all dog lovers!to TeamDogs for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: peppa pig fan 3 named
story: Peppa Pig fan, , named World Puddle Jumping Champion for technique and infectious giggleGrace Crouch has been making a splash in the World Puddle Jumping Championship  - the tot was inspired by her cartoon hero Peppa Pig who loves making a splashGrace Crouch has bagged top prize Image: Cavendish PressLtdByStephen WhiteNews Reporter:,  Nov | commentsPeppa Pig fan Grace Crouch has been crowned this year’s World Puddle Jumping Champion. Inspired by her cartoon hero, who loves making a splash, the three-year-old won over judges with her technique and “infectious giggle”. Grace made a splash with judges of the annual event, organised by Wicksteed Park, Kettering, Northants, which attracted hundreds of online entries from around the world. Competitors taking part in the ninth annual event, held during the October half term holidays, were asked to send in videos of themselves jumping in puddles they’d made or found themselves. They were also invited to use any naturally-formed puddles they found while walking around the Kettering park. Grace, from Northampton, narrowly beat off competition from Jake Watts, , from Desborough, who finished second and Jack Abbott, , from Nuneaton, who was awarded third prize. Judges also gave a Special Achievement Award to Ben King and his son Cassius, four, from Northampton, for their joint entry – Ben holding Cassius in his arms while they jumped. Grace’s prize will include a new pair of wellies and a raincoat donated by clothing and footwear company Joules. Mum, Rachel, said: “Grace is so delighted to have won. She just loves jumping in puddles, and Peppa Pig certainly has a lot to answer for!“Whenever we go out she is always looking for puddles and she makes such big splashes that I often end up getting covered in mud too.” Judges marked entries on things such as the height of the jump, enthusiasm, distance of splash and stickability - the amount of mud which clings to each competitor. Wicksteed Park Head of Sales and Marketing Rachel James said: “We have so much fun with this event each year and judging is very tough, but also hilarious, as we look at all the entries. “As always we had some amazing competitors and the event has certainly been a great way of encouraging people to get out and about in the fresh air and have fun. “One of the things which the judges were looking for was enthusiasm and that, coupled with her infectious giggle and the muddy splat she made were the reasons that Grace just edged first place.” Comment MORE ON Half TermPeppa PigChildrens TV" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: pothole old locals celebrate birthday
story: Pothole so old locals celebrate its birthday - with a caterpillar cakeLocals in Connemara, Ireland realised a troublesome pothole was still there after two years - so they bought it a catepillar cake to celebrate its pbirthdayA troublesome pothole in Connemara, Ireland celebrated its birthday with a caterpillar cake after locals realised it had been unrepaired for two years Image: galwaybeo WSByJessica MercerRyan FaheyReporter:,  Nov | comments A pothole thataposs not been repaired for two years was given a birthday cake to mark the milestone. Locals recently marked the birthday of a hole in the road on the R in Connemara, western Ireland.The big day was also celebrated on social media by a protest group working to highlight the neglect of the communityaposs roads.Connemara Roads re-shared the image two years after it was originally uploaded - to show how long the local council had taken to address the issue.The kid-favourite birthday treat was pictured with the caption: Pot hole on the R celebrates nd birthday today. Dozens of local residents, likely motorists who have driven past the crack, liked the post. The original image was taken in  but it was reposted by the N Action Campaign ahead of a visit from a politician next week. The page shares images of potholes, rips and tears on the road on a regular basis.  Local campaigners spray them with paint to highlight dangers to other motorists. Earlier this year a teacher slammed her local council after a pothole that ripped open two tires on her car was considered not dangerous enough, for her to claim damages. Jeanette East, , incurred £ worth of damage to car when she hit the ft-long, ins-deep crevice in Dedham, Essex. Jeanette, who described the pothole as aposan accident waiting to happenapos, lodged a complaint with Essex County Council following the incident in April, but was sent packing when the damage to the road was deemed not dangerous by an inspector. Now, the disgruntled driver is considering taking the issue before a small claims court.Speaking to Suffolk Live, she said: The unevenness of its surface along thatis lethal for walkers, cyclists and motorcyclists they just won’t see it.Comment MORE ON NHSVehicles" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news prince-harry-blocked-wearing-military-"Prince Harry having military titles stripped will be massive ordeal for himByClaire Gilbody-DickersonNews reporter:,  Nov | commentsPrince Harry will not be able to wear his military unorm when he awards war heroes with medals next week. The Duke of Sussex, , will next week be attending a gala onboard a warship in New York to award five war heroes with medals. But despite him twice serving in Afghanistan, he will not be able to wear his military unorm due to him being stripped of his honorary titles.Harry lost his titles after he and Meghan Markle, , announced in March last year they were abandoning their lives as senior royals to shape their own path abroad. They now live in a multi-million dollar mansion in Montecito, in Calorniaaposs Santa Barbara, with their kids Archie and Lilibet. They had first moved to Vancouver Island in Canada.Harry had wanted to retain the honorary positions, including Captain General of the Royal Marines, but was unable to do so.  It means that he will have to wear plain clothes as he hands out awards at The Salute to Freedom gala on November . He will, however, be able to pin his four medals on his suit to mark the special occasion. The event will pay tribute to those who have served in the US forces, defending America, with the awards honouring those who have demonstrated courage and perseverance in the face of great danger or personal struggle. The museum said: The Intrepid Museumaposs Salute to Freedom gala recognises extraordinary leadership and honors the brave men and women who serve in defense of our nation. Rocker and humanitarian Jon Bon Jovi will also receive the  Intrepid Letime Achievement Award for his work as chairman of the Jon Bon Jovi Soul Foundation. The organisation focuses on breaking the cycle of poverty and homelessness through affordable housing and shelter, including permanent supportive housing for veterans. Jon Bon Jovi recorded a charity single, Unbroken, for Harryaposs Invictus Games Foundation early in . Susan Marenoff-Zausner, president of the Intrepid Museum, said: We are extremely proud to bestow the inaugural Intrepid Valour Awards to five incredible iniduals who have gone above and beyond the call of duty and persevered through extraordinary circumstances. It is a core tenet of our institution to be there for our service members and veterans, who are always there for all of us. One of the ways we fulfil this commitment is by offering meaningful programmes that help veterans reintegrate into civilian le and build connection and community, including ones that specically address mental health.We are so grateful to Prince Harry, The Duke of Sussex for honouring and amplying the stories of these heroes and helping to raise awareness for mental health support for our men and women in unorm.Comment MORE ON Prince HarryRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: scientists unravel women who wear
story: Scientists unravel why women who wear less clothing on nights out dont get coldA study published in the British Journal of Social Psychology named "When looking hot means not feeling cold: Evidence that self-objectication inhibits feelings of being cold" claims to have solved the mysteryA study published in the British Journal of Social Psychology claims to have solved the mystery on how women dont feel cold when they dont wear a lot on chilly nights out Image: Anita Maric   SWNSByLorraine King:,  Nov | commentsTemperatures in the UK are dipping as we head towards winter which means wearing a jacket or a coat is no longer a choice but a necessity.However some women on a night out prefer to ditch their outwear and brave the icy winter weather instead.While onlookers wonder how they are able to endure the chill thereaposs actually a scientic explanation behind it. A study published in the British Journal of Social Psychology named When looking aposhotapos means not feeling cold: Evidence that self-objectication inhibits feelings of being cold claims to have solved the mystery. Roxanne Felig, one of the study authors, revealed on TikTok that when someone is highly focussed on how they appear externally, their everyday needs come second.  She said the study was partly based on Cardi B’s  claim that “a hoe never gets cold,” with Roxanne noting that she and her fellow researchers “wanted to test that scientically”.Roxanne, a social psychology graduate student at the University of South Florida who goes by the username @ naia_papaia on TikTok, said: So basically, it seems like what Cardi was saying was that she was too focussed on how she looked and what she was wearing to feel cold. And this actually aligns perfectly with the main theoretical perspective that I used to conduct my research, which is objectication theory. When women are in a state of objectication, they are less aware of how hungry they are, their heartbeat. They are just less able to recognise their internal states. The research team interviewed women who were queuing to get into clubs over five particularly cold nights in Florida - where temperatures ied between °C and °C.  Participants were then asked how much they typically think on a day-to-day basis about how they look, how many drinks theyaposd had and how cold they felt. The researchers also took anonymous photos of the outfits worn by the women, which were then coded for amount of skin exposure. We found that for women [who ranked] high in self-objectication - regardless of how much skin they have exposed - they wouldnapost feel cold, Roxanne explained. The study concluded: Our hypothesis was supported: women low in self‐objectication showed a positive, intuitive, relationship between skin exposure and perceptions of coldness, but women more highly focused on their appearance did not feel colder when wearing less clothing. title: simple life parents grandparents taught
story: Simple le parents and grandparents taught can help save earth without COP lecturingThe warm and wise words of Mrs Savage- this week Val reflects that important lessons and the simple way of le our parents and grandparents taught us could be key to saving the planet, in Glasgow, Scotland, Britain, November , " content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _COP-in-Glasgow.jpg" width"" "" Masking for it - activists depict leaders at COP Image: REUTERSopinionByVal Savage:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov  - this week Val reflects that important lessons and the simple way of le our parents and grandparents taught us could be key to saving the planet" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _COP-in-Glasgow.jpg" data-tracking"facebook|share|top" - this week Val reflects that important lessons and the simple way of le our parents and grandparents taught us could be key to saving the planet" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _COP-in-Glasgow.jpg" data-tracking"twitter|share|top" - this week Val reflects that important lessons and the simple way of le our parents and grandparents taught us could be key to saving the planet" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _COP-in-Glasgow.jpg" data-tracking"whatsapp|share|top"| commentsWorld leaders flew to Glasgow to plan how we’re going to stop climate change at COP. But I reckon I could cut through the bureaucratic nonsense and give them all a telling. If I was invited to their fancy get-together I’d call all the leaders “babes” so there were no diplomatic incidents. I’d point my walking stick at Boris Johnson and say: “Excuse me babes. Put a mask onyou’re sitting next to Sir David Attenborough or anyone  for that matter. “You’ve been in intensive care with Covid and preaching to the country to wear a mask, now wear one yourself.”Before I took the mic I’d arrange bagpipers to march through the room to make sure everyone was awakeand paying attention.And I’d start my speech by explaining how people of a certain age might not understand all the carbon this and emissions that.Do you agree  Have your say in the comment section But we know how to live a le that’s kinder to our environment because we were brought up that way. Anyone whose parents lived through the war instinctively knows never to waste or throw out food. My mum made leftover meat, always bought from the local butcher, into mince by squeezing it through a mincer attached to the table. She made leftover veg into bubble and squeak, which tasted like a treat and not scraps. Andthere were a couple of slices of stale bread she’d transform them into bread and butter pudding. We didn’t have exotic fruit and weird veg flown from Brazil and wrapped in plastic. We had apples from the nearest orchard, mint, rhubarb and peas from dad’s vegetable patch .  Potatoes and cabbage came from the allotment, milk was collected in a churn from the local farmer. We had what posh people now call an organic diet without realising. Hand-knitted jumpers and not central heating warmed us at home and we kept cosy in bed thanks to extra blankets and a hot water bottle. We even recycled our bathwater by ensuring a whole family washed in one tub. Our streets weren’t littered with takeaway wrappers because we didn’t have any. Instead, food on the go was homemade sandwiches wrapped in greaseproof paper and a rinsed-out and refilled bottle of water. Our roads were quiet because we walked or cycled. Our skies were clearer because we took holidays by bus, not plane. I would swap all of today’s technology for that old le, when few of us had phones at home but we all stopped to speak in the street. We had no time-saving gadgets but time for each other. We had no need for hi-tech doorbell cameras because we all kept our doors open. Everything’s go-go-go now and everyone’s under so much pressure they take tablets like pear drops. We can make the Earth a healthier place by slowing down. We don’t need world leaders lecturing us at COP. Just remember the important lessons and simple way of le our parents and grandparents taught us. We owe it to our grandchildren.It’s easy to lose snooze controlWatching the goings on at COP has been an eye-opener, but not for American President Joe Biden. Looks like he fell asleep during a speech. I understand the importance of the big conference, but I felt for him. Because when your eyes go, you’re gone. He’d just flown from America to Italy and then Glasgow so must’ve been jet lagged. And he’s no spring chicken. Haven’t we all fallen asleep when we really should be paying attention  I know I have. Years back our Robert treated me and his we Sarah’s mum to tickets to watch a tennis match at Wimbledon.  I’m the biggest Wimbledon fan and was up with the larks at am to be on time. Once there, I was so excited my eyes were out on stalks and I wanted to do and see everything. I bought so many souvenirs I’d no money for strawberries and cream so ate an apple instead. But with all the excitement, and the warm sun on my face, I fell asleep while watching the match. Sarah’s mum gently woke me when she saw my head rested on the shoulder of the man sitting next to me. I was mortied. I could blame a boring match. But I was there to see Serena Williams. So I feel for you, Joe.I’ll have my cake and eat it too...This week Sheila made me a whole lime and coconut cake and told me to cut it into thin slices to make it last. It did last: two days.Cleo’s rescue gave me goosebumpsWasn’t it wonderful to see footage of little Australian girl Cleo Smith being rescued.  Looking at her face, hearing how hardened detectives cried when they found her and imagining her parents’ joy made goosebumps rise on my arms and tears fall down my cheeks.Cooked with a gravy kind of loveRestaurant dishes can be as fancy as you like, but they’ll never beat meals home made with care by friends. Janet invited me for Sunday lunch, and it was to die for. Baked Camembert with cranberry sauce and toast soldiers was so tasty I could have eaten six of them. The leg of lamb with mint sauce was delicious. But the gravy, made from meat juices with bits in where the roast potatoes had stuck on the roasting tray, was the best.  No one can make gravy like my mum, but Janet came a very close second. After I’d scooped the last drop out of the gravy boat with a spoon, Janet confessed she’d been hoping to save the gravy for her lunch the next day but was too polite to say. I might never be invited again.Revitalising RyanFilm star Ryan Reynolds’ visit to Wrexham made everyone here feel excited. He is taking the role of revitalising our football team very seriously but said he needs to learn the offside rule. I’m a huge football fan but even I don’t understand offside.  Mind you, I know more than our Robert’s we Sarah. When I asked her who’d scored for Leicester, she said: “A player called OG.”If you would like to contact Val, please email features@mirror. co.uk or write to Val Savage, PO Box , E DD The Mirror makes a donation to the Alzheimer’s Society in lieu of payment. alzheimers.org.ukComment MORE ON FoodLoveClimate changeMental healthAlzheimers diseasePoliticsCOP" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: solar flare spark northern lights
story: Solar flare to spark Northern Lights over UK skies tonight - where to see displayExperts at the Met Office have said that a Northern Light show could hit the UK tonight after a huge cannibal solar flare. Heres how to spot the beautul aurora borealisThe Northern lights as seen over Belhaven bridge in Dunbar, Scotland overnight Image: PAByHarry Thompson:,  Nov | comments The Northern Lights will be visible across the UK tonight thanks to a new solar flare, experts have predicted. Wednesday nightaposs aurora borealis show was visible across much of the south of England due to a phenomenon called coronal mass ejection, caused by huge globs of gas and magnetic field being fired out by the sun.The flares collide with earth and cause a massive geomagnetic storm. It is now thought more flares are on their way with light shows set to continue into tonight.The Met Office aposs Krista Hammond said: As was predicted by the Met Office Space Weather Operations Centre, a coronal mass ejection impacted with the Earth yesterday.“The resulting strong geomagnetic storm meant the Northern Lights were visible across large areas of the UK overnight last night. “We’ve had reports that the aurora could even be seen in some central areas of the UK, which is possible when a storm of this magnitude impacts the Earth.  “This means there is the potential for further sightings of the Northern Lights overnight, although there will be spells of patchy cloud over Scotland which could limit visibility in places.” It is thought the coronal mass ejection left the sun on Tuesday morning and reached earth by the following evening. Where can I see the Northern Lights tonight  Unlike previous opportunities to see the Northern Lights, this weekaposs displays have been visible further south, with people in Devon thought to have a chance of spotting them tonight. As ever though, the best opportunities will be further north, with the Lake District, Scotland, Midlands, Norfolk and North Wales likely to be the safest bets. It is understood that more space weather events are expected over the next four years, into around . Ms Hammon said: This increase in activity is expected as part of this cycle, and we can expect an increase in the number of space weather events as we move towards the next solar maximum. Tips for seeing the lights You need a clear night with as little cloud cover as possible and make sure you get as far away from light pollution as possible. Once youaposve found your spot, look towards the northern horizon and remember that the magnetic activity can have an impact on GPS sources. The issues huge solar flares could potentially cause havoc due to their strong magnetic field. Met office forecasters have said it is possible that: Intermittent GNSS satellite navigation and low-frequency radio navigation problems may occur, HF radio may be intermittent. The storm is regarded as aposcannibalapos because it moved so fast it caught up other solar flares and absorbed them. title: tesla runs out battery blocking
story: Shoppers trapped in car park for  hours after Tesla runs out of battery at exitDrivers caught in the traffic jam were furious about the three-hour delay after the electric-powered car blocked the multi-storey when it lost power on the rampShoppers were fuming after being stuck behind the fancy motor in a shopping centre car park Image: RedditByDan WigginsGraeme Murray:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsFuming shoppers faced a three-hour wait in a car park after a Tesla ran out of battery. Motorists caught in the jam were not happy about the delay after the electric-powered car blocked the multi-storey when it lost power on the ramp. Reddit user Henry was among those who took to the social-networking forum to show their anger at the wait he and other motorists experienced. Other users were also outraged and said there was no excuse for causing such a long delay. After being caught in the jam on Wednesday, Henry posted pictures about the y wait. MyLondon reported his frustration, he said: Perfect, a Tesla ran out of battery and stopped at the ramp of a  storey car park at Westfield. It has been three hours and counting. One of the images he shared with the post showed a tailback of cars looping around the sloped spiral exit ramp. The next, though slightly motion blurred, showed the apparently stricken black Tesla Model S pulled over to the side of the ramp, though still without enough room to pass. According to Tesla, the car has  miles of range when fully charged, so itaposs tough to run out without reaching a charging point. This was exactly the point other users on the forum were making following the delay at Westfieldaposs car park Considering the huge range these cars have, there’s really no excuse for this. One wrote Especially as the cars still have quite a bit of rangeeven after hitting %. The driver had plenty of warning. Another agreed.  Westfield even has a large capacity tesla charging station lol. But yeah like others say over  hours is bad management imo. Get an extension lead at that point. A standard wall plug adds - miles an hour. So just  mins to give it a full mile to drive to a parking spot is needed. Others were less damning of the driver, one writing: Same for running out of petrol I guess. It happens. When users suggested the car should have been recovered already, original poster Henry wrote: The Tesla is completely dead and it is in parking mode. The management team rumbling about their solution and basically there is nothing they can do. At the end, all the car reversed out from a  story winding ramp. Fab day. He also added that attempts to tow the car out had failed. A spokesperson for Westfield said: A customer’s Tesla vehicle broke down on the entry ramp of the car park at around pm due to an empty battery. Westfield London’s car park team assisted the broken down vehicle and guided  vehicles that were behind the Tesla around it. title: thousands young activists march through
story: Thousands of young activists march through Glasgow demanding climate change actionGreta Thunberg joined thousands of other young activists in a march calling for climate change action from leaders and politicians at Cop, which is being held in Glasgow, ScotlandGreta Thunberg joined other young activists on a march through Glasgow Image: NurPhoto PA ImagesByMatthew DreschReporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsThousands of young activists have begun marching through the streets of Glasgow to demand action on climate change from leaders and politicians at Cop. Photographs show the streets lined with crowds of people holding placards demanding change for the future, with participants marching from Kelvingrove Park to George Square. Campaigner Greta Thunberg, fellow activist Vanessa Nakate and other young campaigners, as well as local trade unionists, will speak to crowds at the end of the march through the city where the UN summit is being held. The climate strike has been organised by Fridays for Future Scotland who said they were demanding climate justice and seeking to hold global leaders to account. It comes as the Cop talks feature events highlighting the voice of young people and education in climate action.  At least , people are expected to take part in the march. Ms Thunberg has been highly critical of the two-week conference, claiming it is the most excluding Cop ever and labelling it a two-week celebration of business as usual and blah blah blah. Charlie OaposRourke, , from Glasgow, skipped school to attend the march with his mother Cairsty OaposRourke and sister Edith. He said global leaders at Cop must listen to the people.  He told the PA news agency: Listen to what they want to say. Donapost just go for profit. Listen to what the planet needs. His mother Cairsty said she was there for her children and for the generations to come to just show that something has to happen and it has to happen very quickly.Ms OaposRourke, who is from Glasgow and works for the NHS, said the Scottish Government has been on the fence for too long on the issue of the Cambo oilfield.She added: Iaposd like to hear Nicola Sturgeon saying a bit more against it. Iaposd like all of this funding to go into a way out of this, a way out of using fossil fuels.  Finlay Pringle, , from Ullapool in the Scottish Highlands, travelled by train to Glasgow with his father to take part in the march. He said: If you really, truly love something and you want to protect it, no matter what it is, it doesnapost have to be climate striking, butthereaposs something that you love and you want to protect it, then you should do that, donapost think twice about it. People of all ages have joined the youth-focused protest.  Among them are a group of mothers from around the world, including Rosamund Adoo Kissi Debrah, whose daughter Ella died from an asthma attack as a result of severe air pollution. The group will also be handing in a letter at Cop calling for an end to new fossil fuel financing for the sake of their childrenaposs health and future. The world is at a long-awaited political tipping point in the fight against climate change, former US vice-president Al Gore has said, as he praised youth climate strikers in Glasgow.  Mr Gore, who served two terms as vice-president under Bill Clinton, added that impressive pledges for action have been made at the cityaposs Cop summit in Glasgow. But he warned the climate crisis is getting worse faster than we are yet implementing solutions, as he said more political will is needed to tackle the problem. Speaking at the summit, he said: Young people all around the world are telling us now is the time. In every nation Fridays for Future...outside this meeting hall today.  This is a massive demand by the young people of the world and donapost tell them itaposs impossible. It is possible. We have the tools and we have the ability to this. COP President Alok Sharma said: “Wherever I have been in the world, I have been struck by the passion and the commitment of young people to climate action.The voices of young people must be heard and reflected in these negotiations here at COP. The actions and scrutiny of young people are key to us keeping . alive and creating a net-zero future.  “I am also aware of the fear and anxiety many of them feel about the future of the planet, including my own children. That is why we must act on the COY Global Youth Position Statement from COY and the manesto from the Milan YouthClimate Summit.” YOUNGO Global Focal Points, Heeta Lakhani and Marie-Claire Graf said: “YOUNGO has been working closely with the U.K. Presidency and the UNFCCC Secretariat to co-design Youth and Public Empowerment Day.We successfully profiled global youth voices through the COY Global Youth Statement, and brought together four generations to share best practice examples of achieving climate justice collectively.”  Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Fridayaposs protest comes ahead of marches on Saturday where tens of thousands of people are again expected in Glasgow, with other marches in London and cities around the UK, as well as across the world. Police have warned they will deal swtly and robustly with any violent disorder or damage to property during planned Cop protests in Glasgow over the coming days. Police Scotland Assistant Chief Constable Gary Ritchie said officers have engaged with key campaign groups to ensure the protests can take place safety, but they will quickly crack down on any problemsneed be. The protests come at the end of the first week of the conference, where countries are under pressure to increase ambition on cutting greenhouse gas emissions and to ensure finance for poor countries to tackle the crisis.Comment MORE ON Climate changeCOP" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates from our environment editor on green issues and actions you can takeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: toddler long blonde hair compared
story: Toddler with long blonde hair compared to Boris Johnson after locks grew in lockdownA toddler with long blonde hair is often confused with Prime Minister Boris Johnson according to his mum who fell in love with his "little surfer dude" locks An adorable toddler has been compared to Boris Johnson due to his striking long blonde locks. .Amy Leesons son, Chester, who is -months-old, has distinct bright blonde, long and thick blonde hair that started to grow rapidly when he was four months old - something that has led to him being compared to Boris. .The -year-old from Leicester says that she couldnt imagine her little boy with a dferent hairstyle and that his long blonde suits his free-spirited personality. .SEE CATERS COPY" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _PAY-TODDLER-MISTAKEN-FOR-BORIS-JOHNSON.jpg" width"" "" Chester Leeson, -months-old, and not Prime Minister Boris Johnson Image: Caters News AgencyByBeth KilgallonKieren Williams:,  Nov | comments A toddler with long blonde hair is being compared to Boris Johnson at just -months-old.Chester Leeson has distinct, bright blonde hair that began growing when he was only four months old. His thick locks has given him an uncanny resemblance to the prime ministeraposs own messy hair and led to strangers pointing out the similarity. Chester’s mother, Amy said she could not imagine her son with a dferent hairstyle and it matches his free-spirited, free-loving personality, much like the prime minister. The -year-old said: Chesteraposs hair really started kicking in when he was about four months old when we were in the first lockdown.  I obviously couldnapost take him to the hairdressers for a little trim and I definitely wasnapost going to be taking a pair of scissors to my babyaposs hair so we just let it go. And it just kept growing and growing, but I think it really suits him. People have compared his hair to resembling Boris Johnsonaposs which is hilarious. I think it is the bright blonde colour and thethat make people think that. Heaposs like a little surfer dude. Due to the lockdown, Chester’s hair grew long and thick and Amy did not have the chance to cut it and since fell in love with the style. Chester’s dad, Kieran, , wasn’t as sure on the style at first Amy said, but it has grown on him as well. She added how she often gave him a little top knot now. Even when the country unlocked and she could take her son back to the hairdressers once again, Amy had fallen so in love with the haircut she couldn’t bring herself to have it cut. She added: When we were able to go to the hairdressers we had it trimmed around his face and into more of a little style which I think is adorable. Heaposs got such amazingly thick hair for a little child. I can even plait the top of ithe sits still for long enough. His older brother, Clark, age five, has more golden blonde coloured hair, whereas Chesteraposs is bright blonde, and Clarkaposs is shorter too. His hair never grew as fast as Chesteraposs does. As well as earning comparisons to the prime minister, Amy said Chester is often thought to be a girl because of his hair. Amy says that Chester is also sometimes confused as being a girl because of his hair. She said: I am excited to see where Chesteraposs hair goes. Iaposm happy to leave it growing at the moment and see how it ends up. I love his unique hair and we will keep it like this until he decides he would like to have a haircut. news uk-news two-teenagers-bump-fists-after-"Teenage killers fist-bump to celebrate stabbing a man to deathByBradley Stokes:,  Nov | comments Chilling CCTV footage shows two teenage killers fist-bumping as they celebrated stabbing a man to death in a brutal vigilante murder.Danish Mansha, Rimsha Tariq, and Daiyaan Ar, all aged , scoured the internet to find someone they believed wanted to have violent sex with women. Their victim, Sohail Ali, , was lured to Summerfield Park in Birmingham by the promise of meeting a girl on December  last year. He had been speaking with Tariq online before agreeing to meet with the girl in the park at .pm. Mansha, who was armed with a kne and a blank firing gun, lay in wait with Ar before ambushing Mr Ali who was stabbed seven times as well as being shot.  He was attacked with such force the kne snapped and part of the blade was found embedded in his chest. Mr Ali was rushed to hospital for treatment but died just after midnight. CCTV shows Mansha and Ar fist-bumping each other as they calmly walked away from the murder scene.  They were arrested days later when detectives discovered messages on their phones discussing the attack.The killers were in regular contact with each other days before the murder and Tariq messaged Mr Ali on WhatsApp and Instagram just  minutes before the attack.Following a trial at Coventry Crown Court, Mansha, of Edgbaston, and Tariq, of Walsall, were both found guilty of murder. Mansha, who was also found guilty of possession of a bladed article, was jailed for  years while Tariq was ordered to serve at least nine years before being considered for parole. A third defendant, Daiyan Ar, , of Brandhall, Warley, who was convicted of manslaughter, was jailed for three-and-a-half years. Detective Inspector Laura Harrison, from the homicide team at West Midlands Police, said: This case is really sad. It was a completely senseless attack that took a le and changed three more forever. My officers have worked tirelessly on the case and although todayaposs verdict can never bring Sohail back, I am pleased that we have been able to secure justice for him and his family.  My thoughts are with them at this time. Following the sentencing Mr Aliaposs grieving family said: We are pleased that the defendants were found guilty and sentenced today for the brutal crime they committed. Sadly nothing can bring Sohail back to us. Sohail was murdered needlessly and his le has been stolen from him. The pain that we suffer from his loss is overwhelming. He will forever remain in our hearts. title: what really happened night crooked
story: What really happened night crooked tycoon Robert Maxwell fell to his death from yacht years ago, the crooked tycoon who owned the Mirror Robert Maxwell - father to Ghislaine Maxwell - fell off his yacht. But was it an accident, suicide, or something more sinister Tycoon Robert Maxwel with his yacht in the background Image: DAILY MIRRORByJohn Jackson, Ex-Mirror reporter who travelled with the Maxwell family to scene of tragedy:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsItaposs  years since Robert Maxwell’s naked body was found in the sea off the Canary Islands, his death a mystery which endures to this day. The media mogul, whose company owned the Daily Mirror, had been reported missing by the crew of his luxury yacht hours before the discovery. But Maxwell, a larger-than-le and celebrated figure, soon went from hero to villain as it was found that he had looted millions from the Mirror pension fund to prop up his debt-ridden business empire. His treachery condemned many of his workers to poverty and left his newspapers on the verge of collapse. With the Spanish authorities ruling out foul play and the family insisting he would never take his own le, conspiracy theories abound to this day. Here, former Daily Mirror reporter John Jackson recalls being at the centre of the storm which gripped the world...  Within hours of arriving for work on Tuesday, November , , editor Richard Stott relayed the astonishing news that publisher Robert Maxwell had been lost overboard from his yacht Lady Ghislaine and I was on my way to find him and support family members. With Bonfire Night plans scrapped, photographer Ken Lennox and I took the lt to the roof of the building next to the Mirror, then at London’s Holborn Circus. Maxwell had bought the site to provide himself with a luxury office and helicopter pad. His copter landed and on board were his we Betty, dressed completely in black, and Philip, the eldest of the Maxwell’s remaining seven children . Nothing was said as we hovered over Fleet Street and headed to Farnborough Airport in Hampshire where we boarded one of the family’s Gulfstream jets for the flight to the Canaries. Around an hour later a message was relayed to the pilot that a body had been found in the sea and we were erted to a military base near Las Palmas. At that moment Betty told me: “Whatever has happened, I can assure you he did not kill himself. He would never do that.” We taxied up to the hangar where the body was waiting in the air-sea rescue helicopter. A request for -year-old Betty to climb aboard and make an identication was instantly rebuffed. She told them to bring the body into a nearby room. As this was being arranged – with dficulty as Maxwell was very overweight – the rescue pilot told Betty and me: “I have plucked many bodies from the sea and I just want to tell you he did not drown. There was no water in his lungs.” I then escorted Betty and Philip to view the body of my boss. His skin hadn’t discoloured or wrinkled but what intrigued me was that he was lying with his arms up either side of his head and his hands were clenched.  As a father of four it reminded me of how babies often fall asleep. It was certainly Robert Maxwell. Betty relayed this to editor Stott and the front page headline next morning was “The Man Who Saved The Mirror”. Little did we know of the revelations to follow... From the airport we were driven to board the Lady Ghislaine and start three hectic days with only one thought dominating Betty’s mind. She was determined to get the body released so we could fly it to Jerusalem and arrive before sunset on Friday. Jewish tradition dictates a body must be buried as soon as possible. But we would not be able to land on the Sabbath – Saturday, meaning the burial would be delayed until Sunday, five days after her husband’s death. The next day youngest daughter Ghislaine flew in from New York. At this point I should say I never saw one tear in the eye of we or daughter. Betty admitted the marriage had been falling apart for years and although Ghislaine was her father’s favourite, she remembered the cruel way he often treated the children. Condolences came in non-stop and I took calls from Margaret Thatcher and President George Bush. Philip askedwe could have a quiet word. Tearfully, he said his father hated him and the feeling was mutual. Unlike brothers Ian and Kevin, Philip had no interest in finance and the family business. His sadness was: “Now I will never have the chance to make up with him.” One major obstacle to the Israel journey was that Maxwell’s -stone body in its zinc-lined coffin was far too heavy for the Gulfstream jet. In the end a larger plane was chartered and we all set off early on Friday, arriving just before dusk. In the darkness I could see Betty having a quiet sob, the first sign of a widow in mourning. Two memories of our leaving the Lady Ghislaine for the last time: Betty askedI would carry her handbag, which prompted much mirth from mates ashore.  Not until I read her memoirs years later did I learn that the bag held £, in cash and other treasured items. As we were heading for the gangplank Betty shouted that I should tell Ghislaine to hurry up. I found her in the lounge, instruc­­ting the crew to shred all documents on board. Did she know something  In Jerusalem the family stayed at the historic King David Hotel where they were joined by the remaining children. The Israeli Government afforded Maxwell an elaborate funeral with Philip giving the family eulogy after a speech from the Israeli President. And then he was laid to rest in a plot he had bought on the Mount of Olives and my job was finished. Now the questions – was it suicide, assassination or natural causes  I, one of few people who saw him dead and alive, and spent time on the yacht, am convinced it was natural causes. It is known that at around am on the final morning he telephoned the bridge to complain his cabin was either too hot or too cold. Then he went on deck, naked, to pee over the side. The yacht has a steel barrier around its entirety except by the tenders at the stern where there are two chains. He made his way behind the tenders and then one of two things happened. It is known that he was a very sick man and there is one possibility that he had a heart attack, grabbed the chain, couldn’t hold on and was dead when he hit the water. Or, and we know it was a windy night and the yacht was rolling, he stumbled, grabbed the chain, couldn’t hold on and had a heart attack as he hit the very cold ocean. That would explain three things: the way I saw the body with arms up and hands clenched the rescue pilot’s assertion there was no water in his lungs and Betty’s absolute assurance after  years living with the man, that he would never have killed himself. Back in London, Ghislaine thanked me for all I had done for the family during the fraught and dramatic days after her father’s death. Like all the family, she seemed diminished in her grief. Now, as she sits in a New York jail awaiting trial for her association with paedophile Jeffrey Epstein, I realise that for her that dark day  years ago was just a portent of even darker days to come. title: who guy fawkes  try
story: Who was Guy Fawkes – and why did he try to blow up Parliament in Gunpowder Plot The th of November is still remembered up and down the UK as the day plotters tried to blow up the king and Parliament, when Guy Fawkes was found lurking in Parliament with several barrels of gunpowderEvery year the Gunpowder Plot is remembered Image: Getty ImagesByBenjamin LynchSEO writer:,  Nov | commentsRemember, remember, the fth of November. Gunpowder, treason and plot! Every year the th of November  is indeed remembered, the day a disgruntled man tried to blow up King James I in the Houses of Parliament.His name was Guy Fawkes and was part of a group of Catholic plotters that have been memorialised into British legend ever since. Fawkes has become the face of Bonfire Night every year where effigies are often burnt and fireworks up and down the country are joyfully set off.The plotter has become a major part of British popular culture, the vigilante hero in the  film V for Vendetta even wore the face of Guy Fawkes as a mask So who was Guy Fawkes  Who was Guy Fawkes   Fawkes was born in  in York as a Protestant, but became a staunch Roman Catholic. Being a Catholic in th century England was dficult at that time and they were often persecuted for their beliefs after Henry VIII set the reformation of the church in England in motion. The Stuart king, James I, was Protestant and was expected to become a fair ruler for Catholics and Protestants alike, but he was under fierce pressure in Parliament to resist and impose laws of persecution on Catholics once again. Upon taking the throne, James I introduced fines for Catholics. The likes of Fawkes left England to fight for Catholic Spain against the Protestant Dutch. He adopted the Italian iant of his name aposGuidoapos in order to appear closer to his Catholic faith. He eventually signed his confession as aposGuido Fawkesapos. It is believed that plotters needed Fawkes as his time abroad would make him more unrecognisable as conspirator and harder for the authorities to track. Military experience also helped. The Gunpowder Plot  The plot to assassinate the king and replace him with a Catholic ruler was instigated by plotter Robert Catesby, who was one of the main conspirators alongside Fawkes, Thomas Winter, Thomas Percy, John Wright and Robert Keyes. Seven other accomplices are also known about. The plan was to raze Parliament to the ground and blow up the king at the state opening of Parliament, but an anonymous letter was sent Lord Monteagle, a Catholic, warning him not to attend. The authorities were soon notied and Fawkes was discovered with  barrels of gunpowder in a cellar underneath Parliament on the night of the th to the th of November. When found, he is known to have said that he planned to blow you Scotch beggars back to your native mountains, a reference to James I, who was Scottish. Fawkes was then tortured and gave up the names of his fellow conspirators. The plan was for him to be hung, drawn and quartered, but Fawkes jumped to his death in January . In the aftermath, an act was passed to appoint  November as a day of thanksgiving for aposthe joyful day of deliveranceapos. It meant that the plot was remembered each year officially until , but the custom had become popular and we still celebrate it to this day. As is tradition at the state opening of Parliament, the Houses of Parliament are still searched by the Yeomen of the Guard to make sure there is know Fawkes-wannabe lurking in the chambers below.
