title: jeff bezos new 57m beachside
story: Jeff Bezos new £m beachside mansion could be underwater in  years, expert warnsThe warning comes hot on the heels of Bezos being blasted as an eco-hypocrite for flying to the COP climate summit on a carbon-pumping private jetBezos has recently snapped up a massive estate on the Hawaiian Island of Maui, in the US Image: Google EarthByLucas Cumiskey:,  Nov | comments A £million beachside mansion newly purchased byJeff Bezoscould be underwater in just  years due to rising sea levels linked to global warming, an expert has warned. The billionaire Amazon founder - who recently flew to space in his Blue Origin rocket - has recently snapped up a massive estate on the Hawaiian Island of Maui, in the US.The lavish property boasts its own private bay, set on  acres of land on a paradise island. Bezos, the world’s second richest man, estimated to be worth about £billion - is also reportedly looking into buying more property on Maui.Bezos was recently blasted as an aposeco-hypocriteapos for flying to the COP climate summit on a carbon-pumping private jet.And a climate expert is now claiming the “only reason Jeff Bezos cares” about climate change is because he has bought a property in Maui, Hawaii which could be affected by accelerating sea level rises. Prof Mark Maslin, leading climate scientist from University College London, and author of aposHow to Save Our Planetapos, said: There is something distasteful about a billionaire flying into COP on his private jet to tell the world they must stop climate change. I say letaposs save the planet for the . billion normal people that live on Earth, not the super-rich who could put their money where their mouth is, but do not. Property records reportedly show Bezos purchased three dferent structures on his own private bay, plus extra acerage, under Lochland Holdings LLC. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg reportedly owns more than , acres of land on nearby island Kauai, where heaposs said to have splurged £million on real estate works. On its website, Hawaii State warns: Chronic flooding will lead to an additional , acres of land becoming unusable, and , structures are projected to be at risk due to sea level rise. |About  cultural sites,  miles of major roads, and at least  billion in assets will be vulnerable to chronic flooding. Such widespread flooding could change the character of the islands by affecting cultural heritage, tourism, agriculture, and ecosystems. It adds: Thirteen miles of beaches around the state are already gone, including  per cent of Oaposahuaposs beaches because of coastal erosion.  Seventy per cent of beaches around the state are currently threatened. Prof Maslinaposs stark climate change warning came after the Amazon billionaire pledged £.billion to the Bezos Earth Fund to help restore nature in a COP speech on Tuesday. Bezos, , sparked mockery by saying a recent voyage to space on his high-polluting Blue Origin rocket made him realise how fragile Earth is. He is estimated to have splurged £billion on his private space firm Blue Origin. A spokesperson for the Bezos Earth Fund told The Independent: Jeff uses sustainable aviation fuel, and offsets all carbon emissions from his flights. Meanwhile, Amazon says it is on course to power its operations with  per cent renewable energy by . It has also pledged to reach net zero carbon emission by . However, Amazonaposs absolute carbon emissions reportedly grew  per cent year-over-year in  due to a pandemic online shopping boom. It also reportedly employs , drivers, with , trucks, , vans, and a fleet of jets all pumping out emissions. news weird-news thats-spot-yorkshire-terrier-loves-"Yorkshire terrier loves having hair cut in hilarious videoByCatherine Swan:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsWhen it comes to having a dog, keeping them clean and tidy might be one of the trickiest aspects - a lot of dogs donapost love being groomed, and owners often have to leave it up to a professional. But that wasn’t the case for this Yorkshire Terrier, who definitely seemed to be enjoying the experience of having their fur cut at home in a TikTok video thataposs been making dog lovers giggle.TikTok user @lrfearn posted the hilarious clip, which shows the Yorkie bouncing on their back legs as they get their back fur clipped.The clip is appropriately captioned “Thataposs the spot!”. The pup vibrates so much that they scoot across the floor and the groomer has to keep pulling them back into place. At one point in the video a Staffie comes in and gives the Yorkie a cursory snf, aswondering what theyaposre so pleased about. The clip is made all the more amusing by the hysterical laughter of a child that can be heard in the background.  The video has almost two million views on TikTok, with loads of dog lovers commenting on the pup’s adorable reaction. “The most wholesome thing I have ever seen,” one person gushed. “They just changed her batteries”, another commenter joked. Some also commented that their dog does something similar, kicking their back legs when they find a spot that they seem to love being scratched on.According to Hillaposs Pet Nutrition, this is an involuntary “scratch reflex” that dogs have.The nerves under a dog’s skin mean that when they’re tickled in a particular sweet spot, they just can’t help but kick their legs. It’s said to be an instinct to help protect dogs from things like fleas and ticks. While it may be involuntary, that doesn’t mean the dog isn’t enjoying the scratch action - and judging by the way the Yorkie in this video looks adoringly at their owner, they certainly seem to be having a good time. Of course, getting spruced up isn’t something that every dog loves.This Samoyedstruggled to hide just how much he hated bath time in another amusing TikTok video posted by@boomer_the_landcloud .The video shows Boomer looking increasingly less impressed as he goes reluctantly through the stages of being bathed. The clip ends up with the drenched pup looking very cross that he’s been put through such an ordeal, before his owner gives him a reassuring pet. title: three year old boy inspired
story: Three-year-old boy inspired by his grandfather becomes keen litter pickerYoung Huey Bullingham loves litter picking with his grandfather, -year-old John, and together they regularly pick up discarded rubbish from country roads and beachesHuey Billing is living proof that anyone can do their bit Image: John BullinghamByJohn BettAudience Writer:,  Nov | commentsA three-year-old boy who lives litter picking has become the worldaposs youngest and most adorable environmentalist. Young Huey Billing lives in a remote part of Cornwall with his parents, Mark and Fae, and near his grandfather, -year-old John Bullingham. John likes to pick up litter whenever he spots it, and the habit has been picked up by young Huey, even though he canapost pronounce it properly and calls it aposglitter pickingapos. Together, Huey and John clean the country lanes near their home in Trevone, near Padstow, Cornwall, as well as local beaches that are blighted with litter. John said: Hueyaposs encouraged by me, and he calls it glitter picking which is quite cute.What do you think about Hueyaposs efforts  Let us know in the comments...Iaposve been trying to educate him on the environment and how it helps and heaposs very keen - at three and a half he seems to get it, or heaposs pretending he does Itaposs all around here, or the beach and in the lanes, whenever weaposre out weaposll be picking up litter. Our lane is rural and you get litter thrown out the cars. Iaposve been doing it for years and now Hueyaposs doing it with me, he loves it. There are lots of people that come down the lane and they all congratulate him, and he likes that. John said that he and Huey had been inspired by local community interest company aposBeach apos, who encourage people to get out in their area and do their bit.For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newslettershere. A spokesperson for the Beachteam said: At Beach , we love featuring our aposstarsapos – people of all ages who send us pictures and stories of their beach cleaning and litter picking experiences Whether this is people doing it for the first time, or having done it for years We’re really proud that we have been able to equip over  people in Cornwall so far with litter picking equipment It’s made a massive dference in our communities knowing that people have the equipment and knowledge of what to do through having engaged with us on one of our regular beach cleans, or having watched one of our videos on Youtube.  Meanwhile, it has emerged that millions of Brits admit to leaving litter on a beach and say they will continue to do so - because they donapost take a rubbish bag with them on trips.A study of , adults found almost four in ten have left rubbish behind while on the coast, and  per cent think they will carry on with this bad habit in the future. A third blame it on not being close enough to any bins, but  per cent put it down to not having a bag with them to carry the rubbish home. It also emerged that the average Brit visits a beach eight times a year, with half taking a picnic with them.Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. title: mum receives strange texts men
story: Mum receives strange texts from men over Facebook post about her missing catLinda O Suilleabhain, from Dublin, told a Facebook group that her cat was missing before receiving replies from fake accounts with men telling her to come roundLinda O Suilleabhain wrote a Facebook post about her missing cat Image: DublinLive WSByRoisin CullenTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments A worried mum is warning others after she received strange Facebook message frommen claiming to have her familyaposs missing cat.The Facebook strangers sent messages telling Linda O Suilleabhain, from Dublin, to come round, but she was not taken in by the scam.She told DublinLive how she posted onto a local online group that her family cat Eve had gone missing.But it was then that she received a bizarre reply and she dreads to think what could have happenedshe had gone along with it. Linda said: Eve, the cat went missing on the day after Halloween. The fireworks spooked her and thereaposs been no sign of her since then.  On Tuesday evening, I got a message from a man and judging from his profile it all seemed kind of legit, a picture of him and his we and his grandchild. He said: aposOh I have your missing catapos. Linda immediately asked for a picture of the tabby cat as she was afraid that it might not be her one, but the account stopped replying shortly after Linda asked for photos of the missing cat. She said: When I woke up the next morning and went into the messages, the profile had been deleted. Then I found message requests - three, four, five even. They were similar messages saying aposI have your cat can you come up to my house apos It was all obviously a ploy. It looked so believable. There were so many accounts like that in the space of  hours. I wouldnapost even say thataposs their real photo. Everything was . When I went into the other accounts, the accounts had been set up that day. It was scary. Linda contacted one of the admins of the local Facebook group, Finglas Fianna Fail Councillor Keith Connolly. He quickly changed the settings on the group after hearing Lindaaposs story, before finding and blocking a number of recently set up accounts that had been causing hassle in the group. Cllr Connolly said said: As a result of that I found four profiles that were set up that day. They all had a mutual friend. I think some of them were the same ones that messaged Linda because it looked like the same lad setting up four dferent accounts. He also received a message from one of the fake accounts at :pm, urging him to come fix the hole in their house. Another account posted in about their missing son, something that was later proven to be . Linda worries about what could have happeneda less tech-savvy person had received a message, especiallythey were desperate to find a family cat.. The mother used the messages to teach her -year-old daughter about the dangers of social media and how things arenapost always as the seem. She said: I knew myself I wouldnapost be going to a house without somebody. Iaposd be afraida teenager posed that theyaposd lost something then theyaposd go not thinking, or an elderly person or a vulnerable person. Thataposs where my concern was. They potentially could have gone round and God knows what would have happened. They didnapost have the cat so what did they want to do  Itaposs actually frightening. If I had gone I could have potentially not come back. MirrorOnline has contacted Facebook for comment. news world-news paraplegic-dog-miraculously-learns-walk-"Miracle as paralysed dog learns to walk againByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Nov | commentsA paralysed dog has miraculously learned to walk again after it was bedridden for six months. Puco, two, could barely move from his bed after he was diagnosed with hereditary paraparesis, a neurological disease that weakens and stfens the leg muscles. Ken Jhay Empleo, his owner, patiently nursed the dog back to health. Ken said his pooch had also suffered from heatstroke prior to the diagnosis. Puco was hand-fed and hooked up to an IV drip in their home in Vigan City, the Philippines while undergoing physical therapy every day. After months of round-the-clock care and devotion, the paraplegic dog started to regain his strength.  He is now able to take strolls on his forelegs while wearing a makesht wheelchair to support his lower half last month in October. A heartwarming video has shown little Puco using a makesht wheelchair to explore with another dog. In another scene, Puco is seen walking without the makesht wheelchair and also running around a patio. Ken said: A miracle happened to him. I prayed that, evenhe couldnapost walk anymore, he would recover and regain his energy. I think God really did answer my prayers and gave me hope. Puco now gets by without his wheelchair, roaming Kenaposs home with a playful,unbalanced, spring in his step. In , a dog that was left paralysed in a road accident has been given a new lease of le thanks to a state-of-the-art PEDAL chair which helps her run again.  Puffy a Chinese Crested pooch lost the use of her rear legs when she was struck by a car in January  just days after getting her new home. It destroyed the nerve connection to her hind legs and there was nothing that TV’s Supervet could do to save her legs. But owners Michael and Danielle Cass refused to give up on their disabled pet. Puffy is now far more mobile thanks to the pedal cart from Kerdog. title: rare phone signal remote campsite
story: Rare phone signal at remote campsite helped police track down missing Cleo SmithThe Western Australia Police Force said phone data played a key role in tracing missing four-year-old Cleo Smith after she vanished from a campsite near the town of CarnarvonCleo Smith was rescued by police  days after she went missing Image: Getty ImagesByMatthew DreschReporter:,  Nov Police managed to track down missing four-year-old girl Cleo Smith after tracing phone signals near the Australian outback campsite she vanished from. The remote campsite is located next to three phone towers that were installed in , meaning it has far stronger signal than the nearby town of Carnarvon, Western Australia. Although police have not yet released all the details about how they found Cleo, they have admitted that phone data and a tip-off about a car in the area played a crucial role. Large swathes of the outback are reportedly dead zones for mobile phone signal, meaning it was a stroke of luck that the campsite was near new phone masts. Officers rescued the youngster from a locked home in Carnarvon after arresting Terence Darrell Kelly, who has been charged with forcibly taking a child under  Speaking about the rescue, Western Australia’s Deputy Police Commissioner Col Blanch previously said: “Weaposve collected phone data, witness statements, DNA, fingerprints, rubbish along the highways, CCTV - weaposve collected everything.  “We had to find that needle. Last night the needle in the haystack came out and they acted in a heartbeat. Intelligence led them to that house. They went into that house, Cleo was in the house alone. The moment that Kelly was arrested by police was filmed on Tuesday night in dashcam footage from a taxi. The -year-old could be seen being pulled over by officers and pinned to the ground. About an hour after Kelly was arrested, Cleo was rescued from his locked home, bringing her -day ordeal to an end.  Police broke into the house in Carnarvon, a town about  kmsouth of the campsite, early on Wednesday morning and discovered Cleo in one of the rooms.In moving bodycam footage after she was found, officers can be heard saying Iaposve got you, bubby and whataposs your name, sweetheart  before she replies my name is Cleo. When Cleo went missing on October  she was on the first night of a holiday at the Quobba Blowholes camping ground. The remote site is  miles north of Perth and is known for its sea caves and lagoons.  Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Cleo had gone to bed for the night on an air mattress next to her sisteraposs cot in a tent. When her mum woke up the next day the young girl was gone and the tent door was left open. Ms Smith was adamant that her daughter could not have left the tent by herself, instantly leading to fears that she had been abducted.Most ReadFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Cleo Smith" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. .dct-cta__grid:after.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__label,.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__btn.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__gridgrid-template-columns:fr minmaxgrid-gap:.rem .remPlans to permanently block cars and buses from the central stretch of Union Street could be passed through next week.Decades in the making, calls to halt traffic between Market Street and Bridge Street will be heard by councillors on Friday.It comes as planners redesign the heart of Aberdeen as part of a £ million project to bring people back after Covid and to revitalise the city in a move away from oil and gas.New images have been produced by LDA # the firm who designed the revamped Union Terrace Gardens and the Olympic Park in London.Full business cases on road changes throughout the city centre # outside of the central stretch of Union Street # could be together by the end of next year, paving the way for the huge change.Top council officials are recommending the option to fully pedestrianise Union Street be approved # with an exception for cyclists # along the same stretch currently closed as part of the coronavirus physical distancing changes.Service vehicles would also be allowed into the pedestrianised zone but only during limited hours.To make losing a stretch of the city#s main thoroughfare work, roads bosses are also pressing for an overhaul of Market Street, Bridge Street and Guild Street.There, they want priority to be given to buses, taxis and private hires and bikes.Upperkirkgate and Schoolhill might also be pedestrianised, between Harriet Street and Flourmill Lane, while a ban on vehicles # except buses # turning right from Union Terrace into Rosemount Viaduct is also being recommended.The refresh of the city centre masterplan includes a new £m market on the former British Home Stores site, which was recently backed with £m of UK Government funding.Aberdeen beach is also in line for an overhaul # potentially including a new football stadium to replace Pittodrie, new sports facilities and a revamped Castlegate to improve the seafront#s links with the Granite Mile.Finance convener Ryan Houghton said: “These plans are a hugely ambitious statement of intent for Aberdeen.#They will not only act to heal the city from the economic damage inflicted by Covid-, but will also see us improve the health of our citizens by creating an open, accessible beachfront.#The proposals will breathe new le into our city centre, boost job creation and promote a wealth of opportunities to allow businesses and traders to thrive.#Above all, this new cityscape will bring the city back to the people, giving them easy access to a st century way of living that is open, inclusive and environmentally friendly.#Proposals to permanently ban cars from the central stretch of the city#s main thoroughfare first emerged  years ago.Angry bosses at the city#s two largest bus operators # Stagecoach Bluebird and First Aberdeen # recently penned an open letter to roads planners, demanding their access be reinstated to the stretch now set for permanent pedestrianisation.Their seven busiest stops sit on the stretch.Town House chiefs have noted public opinion on accessible parking, cycling facilities, bus stops and routing, taxi ranks and servicing arrangements and are promising more consultation on the concerns.Vice-convener and council leader, Jenny Laing, said: “The council is proud to put forward this report detailing the potential £m transformation of Aberdeen’s beach and city centre.#The report, and the detailed projects outlined within it, show the depth and breadth of our ambition, and our commitment to bring real, positive change for the people of Aberdeen.#Councillors will consider the plans at a meeting of the city growth committee on Friday.Financial details, as the local authority considers entering contracts for ious projects, will be discussed in private.

.dct-cta__grid:after.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__label,.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__btn.dct-cta--signup .dct-cta__gridgrid-template-columns:fr minmaxgrid-gap:.rem .remWith the Covid- vaccination programme now under way, we#ve put together a collection of Covid vaccine tracker charts to monitor the progress of the Covid- vaccine rollout across the UK.How many people have been vaccinated How many people have received the vaccine in my area Which demographics have received the vaccine What is the uptake like during pregnancy The Covid vaccine tracker below shows an at-a-glance view of the current proportion of the Scottish population who have received the first and second dose of either the Oxford AstraZaneca or the Pfizer BioNTech vaccination so far.Data on the number of people vaccinated was initially provided in a weekly report from Public Health Scotland, however there was immense pressure to keep the public more regularly informed so on January  the statistics began to be provided each day.The chart below shows the daily numbers of first and second doses provided.The chart below shows the cumulative number of people who have received each dose since the vaccination programme began on December .It#s also helpful to look at this data as a proportion of the Scottish population so you can see how the percentage of people vaccinated grows over time.The chart below shows the progress for each UK country.On January , Public Health Scotland provided this data broken down by vaccine type which is shown in the chart below.The map below shows the available data on the regional rollout of the vaccination programme.January  saw the release of data by local authority area for the first time, which is shown in the map below.Regional data was originally available on a weekly basis but moved to a daily upload on February . The chart below contains data on the daily number of doses provided and the population covered. Use the drop down box to select your area and the buttons to move between daily vaccinations, cumulative vaccinations and the percentage of the population who have received first doses.Similarly to the regional data, data by demographics were originally provided in the weekly PHS report # however on February  they moved to a daily publication schedule.The chart below shows the daily number of people who have had first doses in each age range as well as the percentage of that population covered.There is limited data available on vaccinations in pregnancy, however we do have monthly data on the number of people vaccinated by pregnancy trimester.Coronavirus in Scotland # track the spread with these charts" title"#Coronavirus in Scotland # track the spread with these charts# # Evening Express" src"https:www.eveningexpress fp news specials coronavirus-in-scotland-track-the-spread-in-these-charts-and-maps embed # secretanuYMBbtv" data-secret"anuYMBbtv" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"Coronavirus in Scotland – here are the key demographics" title"#Coronavirus in Scotland – here are the key demographics# # Evening Express" src"https:www.eveningexpress fp news specials coronavirus-in-scotland-here-are-the-key-demographics embed # secretbLHWrhpUp" data-secret"bLHWrhpUp" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"Let us knowthere is something  you think we should be tracking by emailing lkelly@dctmedia

title: star return to league action with victory
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.RJD-sponsored Red Star travelled to Ballerup, East Kilbride on Saturday October  to play their first league game since February  and ed home with three points after an excellent overall performance.The visitors started the game on the front foot and could have been ahead after three minutes when Fraser Talbot#s long range effort came crashing back off the bar.Star didn#t have long to wait before they opened the scoring, however, as Stuart MacLean reacted quickest to a slip in the Duncanrig defence to put his side ahead four minutes later.Talbot again came close to his first Red Star goal but was denied by the crossbar for the second time after finding space to shoot in the box.The lead was doubled soon after when Aaron Moore linked up well with Stuart MacLean on the right channel and powered his shot through the hands of the Duncanrig keeper.Star had several chances to make the game safe in the opening half hour with Craig Aitken and Andy Weir providing the ammunition from the wide areas but the final touch was slightly lacking.Coll McCallum was next to rattle the bar as his long-range effort took a bizzare bounce over the keeper#s head but the woodwork was once again kind to the hosts.Duncanrig pulled themselves back into the game with a rare attack which saw Star switch off and concede a disappointing goal as the midfielder was able to burst through the Star spine unchallenged to leave Ally Lewis with no chance.This stung Star back into action and the two-goal cushion was restored before the break when an excellent counter-attack saw Talbot lay a perfectly weighted pass into the path of Aitken, who finished with great composure to give Star a - lead at half time.Star looked to put the game to bed as quickly as possible in the second half and did so as Aaron Moore grabbed his second of the afternoon following a slip from the Duncanrig keeper.MacLean was next to double his tally as he proved too sharp for the Duncanrig defence and finished well from a tight angle to make the score - with half an hour to go.This gave manager Weir the chance to ring the changes, with Ryan Caskie coming on to replace Aaron Moore and helping himself to two goals of his own from close range to make the final score -.The only sour note was an injury to goal-scoring substitute Caskie which will rule him out of Star#s next game.Star look to make it back-to-back wins on Saturday October , again on their travels to Port Glasgow OBU.

title: excellent-performances-gala-harriers-scone-palace
story: A NUMBER of runners from Gala Harriers took part in the Scottish National Cross-Country Relays at Scone Palace on Saturday.Kirsty Rankinegot off to a great start over the fast .k course to hand over to Erin Grayin th. Erin had an excellent run, pulling the girls back to th, leaving U Isla Paterson for the final leg. This brought the girls home in a very well-deserved th. In this event, Gala also fielded an incomplete team ndash with Kacie Brownand Poppy Lunngetting their first taste of national relays and running very well at this level of competition.Next up were the boys. A total of  teams toed the starting line and Archie Dalgliesh set off for the Us, fighting his way through the field and handing over to U Zico Field in th. Zico had a strong run and pulled back a few places to th, leaving Ewan Christie for what was possibly the Gala run of the day. He charged through the field and held on for a fantastic th overall  The second Gala team ndash consisting of Charlie Dalgliesh, Ross Christie and Cameron Rankine ndash also ran strongly and finished th overall.The Senior and Masters teams raced over a scenic km loop.Three teams featured for Gala in the omens race. The A team were given a great start by Sara Green with a strong opening leg of : minutes. Fantastic support was then provided by Lizzie Macleish , Lisa Dalglieshand Charlotte Hendryfor a th place finish overall.On paper the W team looked to be well-balanced with strong runners in all positions and so it proved. Gill Lunn , Pamela Baillieand Katy Bardencombined for th place overall ndash just over  seconds outside of the medal spots.The highlight of the day for the Gala team was a bronze-medal winning performance from the W team. Terric performances from Julie Johnstone , Lindsay Dunand Carole Fortuneproved good enough for rd place.The M team of Gary Trewartha , Brian Aitchison , Graeme Murdochand Wayne Mcintoshgave their all and left the course happy and with a bronze medal around their necks. However, subsequent revisions to the results relegated the team to th place in the M category..removeDarrell Hastie led the senior mens team out in typically fast fashion with a : minute leg. The baton was then passed to Fergus Johnston , Paul Hendersonand Iain Buckley , resulting in th place overall. club.The forever-young Bob Johnson completed the teams efforts running a solid solo leg in :.

title: peebles-man-lost-father-covid-formed-ppe-company
story: AN INTERNATIONAL company formed by a Peebles man in the wake of the pandemic to manufacture vital PPE has sponsored local National Hunt Jockey Ryan Mania.Cameron lsquoCammyrsquo Young felt the brunt of the global pandemic early on when he tragically lost his father to COVID-.Further impacting him, his mother was then hospitalised only one month later but has since made a full recovery.Having seen first-hand the overwhelming effects of this disease, Cameron decided to put together a plan to make a dference.In just a few months, it became apparent that the lack of PPE in Scotland and hospitals all over the world was becoming a signicant problem and he decided to step in and be a part of the solution.He founded Envelicus Ltd an international firm focused on the manufacturing of Nitrile and Latex gloves.Utilizing a factory-direct model, Envelicus has established capacity contracts and partnerships with some of the best factories in the world for global production and distribution.The Envelicus mission is ldquoPutting gloves on the hands of the people who need them.With strong ties to the region, Envelicus decided to sponsor Borders jockey Ryan Mania.The pair met during their time as common riding principles in  and have remained good friends.

title: massive-game-vale-raydale-park
story: VALE OF Leithen face arguably their biggest game in years this Saturday when they take on fellow Lowland League strugglers Gretna at Raydale Park.The Dumfries and Galloway side, who replaced manager Rowan Alexander with Stephen Hatfield last month, are currently six points ahead of Vale.New Vale head coach Grant Sandison is looking forward to the challenge after witnessing signs of encouragement against Edinburgh University in his first game in charge.After a string of heavy defeats, the club, with four new faces in the starting line-up, limited the students to three goals.But the Innerleithen side created a number of chances of their own and were unlucky to go in at half-time one goal down.Sandison told the Peeblesshire News: ldquoI was happy with the first-half performance against Edinburgh University."We set up to be organised and to stop conceding goals and I think we limited them to one shot before they scored from a direct free kick just before half-time. We created two or three good chances but in the second half we conceded early from a mistake and then ran out of steam but overall I was happy with the performance.ldquoWe had four players making their debut, Andrew Mackay, Ben Viola and Lewis Grahame who all signed from Penicuik and Ben Brady, who had just been released by St Mirren played as a trialist.ldquoBenpicked up an injury the second-half and had to go off. Hersquos had issues with his ankle all season and went over on it. He didnrsquot train on Monday night, so wersquoll see how he is for Saturday.ldquoWe have another three players lined up that we like the look of but whether they will be signed and available for Saturday, I donrsquot know right now. Hopefully one or two may be able to play.ldquoSaturday will be a massive game for the club. The Edinburgh Uni and Gretna games probably came a bit too early for us."It would have been betterwersquod had three or four weeks with the players first, but it is what it is. I watched Gretnarsquos Scottish Cup game against Berwick Rangers and have received some reports on them but they have a new manager so their style of play may have changed..removeldquoBut Irsquove been delighted with the response of the players so far. There has been a good reaction and there was a real enthusiasm in training. I am really looking forward to the game and it would be great to claw back some points to bring back up the road.

title: borders-recorded-30-coronavirus-cases-last-day
story: THE Borders has recorded  new cases of coronavirusin the last day, latest figures show.According to Scottish Government data published at pm today , the Borders has now seen , cases of the virus since the start of the pandemic.There are  people in the hospital in the Borders with confirmed cases of the virus ndash two fewer than yesterday.Scotland has now recorded , cases of the virus since March last year, according to the latest data.

title: faw-side-wind-farm-fate-settled-public-inquiry
story: A PUBLIC inquiry into a wind farm rejected by Borders councillors will be held next year.Faw Side wind farm ndash which would straddle the Borders and Dumfries and Galloway ndash was opposed by Scottish Borders Councilrsquosplanning and building standards committee in March.The fate of the project, which developers Community Windpower say could provide electricity to more than , homes, will now be settled via a public inquiry.On the inquiry, Gillian Cropper, projects director at Community Windpower, said: ldquoThe planning application in respect of Faw Side community wind farm has been referred to the DPEA and a public inquiry will be held during .:Postal worker who organised illegal rave in Borders during pandemic avoids jailldquoThis is welcomed by Community Windpower, as this onshore wind farm project can play a vital and signicant role in the action required to help tackle the climate emergency and reduce carbon emissions as Scotland works towards its legally binding net zero targets.ldquoAs world leaders attend COP in Glasgow, we are all aware that the time to act is now,we want to have any success in limiting global temperature rise to . degrees to protect the planet for future generations. This wind farm is one step towards achieving this, whilst at the same time, contributing towards a green recovery from the COVID- pandemic.SBC declared a climate emergency back in September last year.However, councillors rejected the -turbine plans this year, stating that it was not ldquothe right place for the development.Following the meeting, Ms Cropper said that local authorities ldquospeak with forked tongues, adding that ldquono one is standing up for the climate.Of the  turbines ndash the tallest of which would reach m ndash  would be situated in the Borders.:Two Borders schools recognised for educational excellencersquoMs Cropper says the project will ldquosupport at least  jobs in construction and create six permanent jobs once operational..removeShe added: ldquoFaw Side community wind farm will also provide economic investment of over pound. billion into the Borders and across Scotland over the -year le of the wind farm.South Scotland MSP Colin Smyth, of Scottish Labour, wrote a letter of objection to the government about the plans in .ldquoI am happy that there is now going to be a public inquiry about this project, he said. ldquoI expressed my objections back in  and my thoughts havenrsquot changed.ldquoWhile a number of constituents had contacted me about the lack of proper consultation about the project, this wasnrsquot the only issue.:Coronavirus: Data shows Borders recorded more than  cases in -hour periodldquoThe area in question is extremely rural and the strain on the local road infrastructure from transporting components from Lockerbie to Faw Side would be enormous, he added.ldquoThe proposals for air safety lighting on the turbines would also have an adverse impact on the local landscape.ldquoI will look forward to the findings of the public inquiry and I hope the Scottish Government takes its evidence and the views of the local community very seriously.

title: galashiels-baptist-church-welcomes-new-minister
story: A BORDERS church is ldquodelighted to welcome its new pastor, with more than  people gathering for his Service of Induction.During the service on Saturday, October  at Galashiels Baptist Church, Reverend Euan Johnstone was ordained as a Baptist minister.Galashiels Baptist Church is the first church Rev. Johnstone will be minister of since completing his studies.Church chairperson Valerie Gelder said: ldquoWe are delighted that Euan has accepted the call to Galashiels Baptist Church and are confident his youthful enthusiasm will help guide the church and benefit the local community.Euan completed a degree in Theology at St Andrews University before working with Christian charity Young Le International in Perth.Joined by his we Beth, Rev. Johnstone ndash who is a keen hillwalker ndash will be the churchrsquos first minister since . Rev. Johnstone said: ldquoWe are so grateful for the warm welcome we have received from Galashiels Baptist Church.ldquoI look forward to getting to know the church more in the exciting weeks ahead as we seek to share Godrsquos love with those around us. And I canrsquot wait to get out and about meeting folks in Gala!Services at the Victoria Street church have resumed and take place every Sunday at .am. Services can also be joined by Zoom.Midweek activities such as a lunch club for the elderly, a parents, carers and toddlers group, a crafts club and youth club have also recommenced.You might also be interested in:Public inquiry to settle fate of -turbinewind farm opposed by Borders councilTwo Borders schools recognised for educational excellencersquoCoronavirus: Data shows Borders recorded more than casesin -hour period

title: unaccompanied-asylum-seeking-children-supported-borders
story: THE Borders will play its part in supporting unaccompanied asylum-seeking children after elected officials backed the councilrsquos involvement in a UK-wide scheme.The national transfer scheme for unaccompanied asylum-seeking childrenwas discussed at a recent full Scottish Borders Councilmeeting.In June, the Home Office announced changes to the scheme, encouraging more local authorities to get involved so that responsibility for the children ldquowill be more fairly distributed.And SBC will now comply with the request for ldquourgent national support for this vulnerable group following unanimous approval.:NHS Borders lsquowelcomesrsquo support as extra military personnel set to be drafted inA report put to councillors states: ldquoGiven the current uneven distribution of UASC across the United Kingdom, the Home Office expect to re-balance the distribution over a two-year period.ldquoThe Scottish Borders are expected to take two UASC within each cycle. It is anticipated that there will be two or three cycles within the first year, and thereafter one cycle per year.The majority of young people within the scheme are aged over , are male and originate from a number of countries, including Iraq, Iran, Afghanistan, Sudan, Eritrea and Vietnam, according to the report.A daily amount of pound is payable to councils for each lsquolooked afterrsquo UASC they host, the report adds, equating to pound, per week.UASC are designated as lsquolooked after childrenrsquo up until  years of age and thereafter as lsquocare leaversrsquo, and are eligible for support until they are  years of age.A weekly amount of pound is payable to councils for each UASC care leaver, according to the report.:Galashiels man who pleaded guilty to possession of class A drug is jailedDuring the meeting, Kelso councillor Tom Weatherston, SBCrsquos vice convener, said the number of children the council is taking on is ldquonot large and that ldquosuitable placements for the first cycle are in place..removeThe Conservative member added: ldquoThis is the right thing to do. We can provide a home for these young people who have been forced to leave their countries.East Berwickshire councillor Helen Laing, of the SNP, said she hoped the children would see the Borders as their new home.Back in June, Vicky Ford, who was then a UK Government minister for children and families, said: ldquoUnaccompanied asylum-seeking children can be some of the most vulnerable in our care, having often faced dreadful exploitation from traffickers.ldquoWe know that many areas have played their part to date but itrsquos absolutely right that local authorities around the country step up and share the role of supporting these young people to settle where appropriate and make valuable contributions to their communities.

title: remember-remember-fifth-sixth-november
story: A number or organised fireworks displays are taking place in the Borders over the weekend   November .The Border Union Bonfire Night takes place at the Border Events Centre in Springwood Park Kelso on Friday  November. Gates open from :pm with Food Refreshments and Kids Entertainment.No sparklers will be allowed and all children under  must be accompanied by an adult. The cost to enter is pound. per car and donations to the BUAS are welcomed.Please note organisers say that the display is subject to cancellation.In addition organised displays are also being held at other venues throughout the region.The Peebles display organised by Peebles Round Table and Stobo Castle Health Spa will take place at Victoria Park on Saturday  November. The bonfire will be lit at .pm and the fireworks are scheduled to start at .pm.Suggested donations are pound. per adult and can be made at localgiving.org peeblesfireworksThe Denholm display takes place on the village green. The bonfire will be lit at .pm and the fireworks are scheduled to start at .pm.The Gattonside display will be held on the village green. The bonfire will be lit at .pm.If you know of any other organised event, please add details to the comments section of this article.A spokesperson for the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service said: ldquoIf you are unable to attend an organised display, we would ask you to consider the impact of fireworks on people and animals. It is often children rather than adults who are injured by fireworks.ldquoThe noise and lights that fireworks emit can also be overwhelming for people with a sensory impairment and those with neurological dferences such as autism. Animals can also find fireworks particularly distressing.

title: great-borders-river-clean-help-make-difference
story: THE Great Borders River Clean s to the region this weekend, helping to clear up local rivers and natural spaces.Covering  areas of the Borders, the event invites locals to join together to help remove rubbish from riverbanks and surrounding areas.Organised by Tom Rawson, the founder of GreenTweed Eco, it will begin on Friday and will run until Sunday.:Coronavirus: Outbreak at Borders school sees parents contacted, says councilldquoThis weekend marks a great weekend of environmental action as communities and groups come together in support of the natural world and the global leaders working so hard to reach agreements at COP down the road, said Mr Rawson.ldquoThe Great Borders River Clean is a regional-scale event where iniduals really can make a measurable, positive dference.On Fridayvolunteers in Ancrum will meet at Ancrum Football Club at pm. Then on Saturday, river cleans will be taking place in: Peebles , Melrose , Darnick , Chirnside , Tweedbank , Galashiels , and Coldstream .On Sunday, November , towns taking part in the river clean include: Innerleithen , Traquair , Walkerburn , Earlston , Hawick , Selkirk , and Kelso .Dates and times are yet to be confirmed for Leaderfoot, Stow and West Linton.:Several organised fireworks displays in Borders this weekendMr Rawson added: ldquoWith the support of Tweed Forum and the Fallago Environment Foundation, the Great Borders River Clean has grown into one of the countryrsquos largest river cleans.ldquoThe Spring  Great Borders River Clean saw nearly  volunteers clear over ,kg of rubbish from Borders river systems..removeldquoAll you need to do to join in is to look at the facebook greentweed.eco page to find an event near you, wrap up warm, bring bags and gloves and get stuck in.ldquoYou really will be making a massive and highly visible positive dference.

title: coronavirus-borders-recycling-centres-close-due-virus
story: TWO recycling centres in the Borders have closed due to a member of staff testing positive for coronavirus.The community recycling centres at Eshiels and Hawick will close for the remainder of today .A Tweet shared by Scottish Borders Council today at .pm reads: "Our community recycling centres at Hawick and Eshiels will be closed for the remainder of today after a member of staff tested positive for COVID-."UPDATE: The two recycling centres are open as normal today .

title: not-take-rugby-match-borders
story: Another feast of live rugby is taking place in the region and beyond this weekend including a Premiership Borders derby between Selkirk and Jed-Forest at Philiphaugh. Elsewhere Hawick travel to league leaders Currie.In National League Division One Gala will take the long trip to face Highland, Melrose host Ayr, Kelso are in the capital to meet Watsonians and Biggar host Boroughmuir at Hartree Mill.In National League Division Two Peebles welcome Glasgow Accies.In National League Division Three Berwick host Strathmore.In National East League One Duns host Linlithgow.In National East League Two Hawick Linden have a home game against Livingston.In the Tennentrsquos East Reserve League One Hawick Force have an away game at Currie A whilst Selkirk A host Jed-Forest A.In the Tennentrsquos East Reserve League Two Gala A are away to Linlithgow A, Melrose Storm host Watsonians A and Peebles Reds take on Kelso Sharks at the Gytes.In the Semi-Junior Border League Jed Thistle host Tynedale Colts, Selkirk Youth are at home to Carlisle Colts, Kelso Harlequins take on Hawick Youth at Poynder Park, Melrose Wasps host a Borders derby against Gala Wanderers at the Greenyards and Peebles Colts welcome Duns Colts.On Sunday Scotland take on Australia in the second game of the Autumn Series at BT Murrayfield. title: borders-buses-cancels-service-due-coronavirus
story: A BORDERS Buses services will not run today due to an ongoing outbreak of coronavirus.The X service ndash which operates between Galashiels and Hawick ndash will not run today following initial cancellations on Wednesday .A Borders Buses spokesperson said: "We had expected to cancel more journeys on more routes tomorrow, however our team ndash who are going above and beyond ndash are working round the clock to keep our buses moving."Services which are cancelled today include:X from Hawick ndash  Hawick to Galashiels X from Galashiels ndash  Galashiels to Hawick   Galashiels to Hawick The earlier  Hawick to Galashiels  and  Hawick to Galashiels  services, as well as the  Galashiels to Hawick  services were also cancelled.The spokesperson added: "We would like to highlight many of our drivers are giving up their much needed day off to ensure our customers can travel."This is a huge testament to our amazing team, and we ask you ndash where relevant ndash to recognise their efforts."As you can imagine the outbreak is once again causing anxiety, so we are reinforcing the hands, face and space message to our team and customers."We shall do our upmost to keep our customers updated on any further changes."

title: tesco-gala-helps-raise-funds-three-worthwhile-charities
story: SHOPPERS in Galashiels have been thanked for contributing towards the poundmillion raised for three le-saving charities as part of Tescorsquos lsquoHelping you to live healthierrsquo initiative.Tesco customers reached the landmark total for Cancer Research UK, the British Heart Foundation and Diabetes UK from - September by rounding up their shop in store to the nearest pound.The funds raised will now help the three charities continue their vital work to save and improve lives.In addition to the poundmillion donated, the campaign raised awareness in Galashiels about the importance of people making sustainable lestyle changes that can help lower their risk of cancer, heart and circulatory diseases, and type  diabetes.This was done with the help of trusted health information and advice, which was shared to empower Tesco customers to take small steps to help improve their health.Oonagh Turnbull, Head of Health Campaigns at Tesco, thankedshoppers in Galashiels for their generosity, which will make a signicant dference to many peoplersquos lives.She added: ldquoIt has been inspiring to see our customers really engage with the work we are doing together, and we hope that we have played a part in raising awareness for these conditions, as well as le-saving funds.The campaign was part of the Health Charity Partnership between Tesco, Cancer Research UK, the British Heart Foundation and Diabetes UK, which aims to inspire and support Tesco colleagues, customers and their families to make healthier food choices and live healthier lives.On behalf of the charity partners , Claire Sadler, Executive Director of Marketing, Fundraising and Engagement at the British Heart Foundation, said: ldquoWe have been amazed by the incredible generosity of Tesco customers and colleagues and would like to thank everyone who donated during September.ldquoYour donations will help to empower millions of people to make healthier choices that lower their risk of heart and circulatory diseases, cancer, and diabetes. It will also help our charities provide vital support to millions of people at a time itrsquos never been more needed, and it will fund research with the potential to save lives.

title: christine-grahame-turn-galashiels-shop-new-office
story: AN MSP will turn a shop on Galashiels High Street into her constituency office after plans were approved by the council.Christine Grahame, an SNP representative for Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale, will take over the space occupied by The Enchanted Florist.Despite stating that a retail unit would have been ldquopreferred, Scottish Borders Council officers have given the green light to change the use of the property to an office.:Borders Buses: Service cancellations continue following coronavirus outbreakOn the decision, Ms Grahame said: ldquoI am pleased that I can now move forward and re-open a constituency office in Galashiels, where I have been for the last  years ndash it is central to the constituency with good public transport links which is essential.ldquoWith some necessary adaptations due to COVID and for security purposes I hope it will be fully ing before the end of the year.ldquoIn the meantime my Tesco surgeries in Galashiels and Peebles will commence this month and you can still, as always, contact me and my staff by phone or email or by writing to me at parliament ndash details are on my website.

title: linda-mccall-borders-council-admits-liability-civil-case
story: SCOTTISH Borders Councilhas reportedly admitted liability after a teacher was convicted of assaulting children with learning dficulties.Linda McCall was found guilty earlier this year of assaulting five pupils between August  and October  while employed by the local authority, as well as one count of threatening or abusive behaviour.McCall had previously been cleared of any wrongdoing after an internal investigation was carried out by the council following complaints from parents.:Borders woman appears at court on consecutive days for breaching bail conditionsOn reports that SBC has now admitted liability in the civil case launched by the parents, Christine Grahame ndash MSP for Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale constituency ndash has accused the council of ldquoan abhorrent breach of trust.ldquoThe parents have now been vindicated in both the criminal court and civil court, however this I know is cold comfort, the SNP representative said. ldquoAt the centre of all this we have young children, often non verbal and unable to clearly communicate, who have been traumatised by the abuse they endured, abuse which they were unable to understand or communicate to anyone.ldquoIt is an abhorrent breach of trust by those we trust to care for the most vulnerable in society and SBC must face up to its role in this.Ms Grahame added that it has been ldquothree and a half years of an uphill slog to try and get a semblance of justice for these families.:Borders Buses: Service cancellations continue following coronavirus outbreakAn independent inquiry into how the council dealt with complaints made about McCall is currently ongoing.A Scottish Borders Council spokesperson said: ldquoThis remains an ongoing legal matter, which is being undertaken on behalf of Scottish Borders Council by external solicitors, and it has not yet been finalised. We have no further comment to make at this stage..removeldquoAn independent inquiry led by Andrew Webster QC, which is considering the councilrsquos handling of concerns raised about the former employee, is still ongoing. As soon as this work is completed we will look to share its outcomes.

title: a7-skippers-wall-lane-closures-impact-motorists-2-weeks
story: DAYTIME lane closures will impact a major road for two weeks, Borders motorists are being warned.Maintenance and upgrade works are planned at the A Skippers Wall - at the north end of Skippers Bridge, which carries the A over the River Esk south of Langholm.Works will begin on the morning of Monday, November , and will end in the afternoon on Friday, December .The lane closure will be between am and pm on each weekday, according to a BEAR Scotland spokesperson.:Borders Buses: Service cancellations continue following coronavirus outbreakChris Tracey, BEAR Scotlandrsquos south east network manager, said: ldquoThis lane closure is essential to allow us to maintain and upgrade the A Skippers Wall.ldquoWe have scheduled the works during daylight hours to enhance the safety of road users and BEAR personnel.ldquoWe have planned the works to minimise disruption, howeveryou do need to use this route during this period our advice is to plan ahead and allow extra time for your journey.During the works, BEAR Scotland will ldquorepoint defective areas of the masonry wall, cut the vegetation above the wall and install timber fencing for the safety of personnel on future maintenance activities.

title: booster-jab-bookings-extended-month-advance
story: People will be able to book their Covid- booster jab a month before they are eligible from Monday.The NHS is changing the booking system to allow people in England to arrange an appointment a month in advance, as the health service aims to ramp up vaccination uptake ahead of a ldquochallenging winter.Currently, anyone eligible who had their second dose of a coronavirus vaccine six months ago can only book their top-up once those six months are up.The update means that people can pre-book an appointment after five months, allowing them to roll up their sleeve on the day they reach the six-month milestone.Health authorities hope this will speed up the booster rollout, strengthen the populationrsquos waning immunity to the virus and help reduce pressures on the NHS.Health Secretary Sajid Javid said: ldquoCovid- vaccines are the best way to protect yourself and your family ahead of a challenging winter and this change to the booking system will make it as easy as possible for people to book their booster jabs.ldquoThis will accelerate the booster programme, ensure the NHS is able to vaccinate people as quickly as possible, and importantly help more people maintain protection against Covid- as we know immunity will dip over time.This autumn winter itrsquos essential you protect yourself and others against both flu and COVID-.If youre eligible, book your flu and COVID- booster vaccines now. https:t.co xspJfkIQDjpic pMjBVWHcEmdash NHS England and NHS ImprovementNovember , People can also book by calling  or turn up without an appointment at hundreds of walk-in vaccination sites across England six months after their second dose to get their top-up.NHS England said more than nine million people have already had a top-up vaccine, and it wants to see those numbers bolstered ahead of colder winter weather which typically leads to increased virus transmission..removeNHS national medical director Stephen Powis said: ldquoWhile this winter is undoubtedly going to be dferent, the most important thing you can do is come forward for both your Covid booster and flu jab as soon as possible ndash now with the added convenience of booking in advance ndash making it even easier to protect yourself and loves ones.vw,vw,px, px"London Mayor Sadiq Khan receives his flu and Covid- booster jab People entitled to a booster jab are those aged  and over, people who live and work in care homes, frontline health and social care workers, people aged  and over with a health condition that puts them at high risk of getting seriously ill from Covid-, those aged  and over who are a main carer for someone at high risk from the virus, and people aged  and over who live with someone who is more likely to get infections.The NHS is also urging those eligible for a free flu vaccination to take up the offer..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Booster jab bookings extended to a month in advance

title: scotland-v-australia-channel-scotland-rugby-game
story: Scotlandwill play Australia in their second match of the rugbyautumn series this weekend at Murrayfield.Last week the team played against Tonga in front of a home crowd, winning - in an impressive match.Now turning their attention to Australia, the odds look slightly tipped in Scotlands favour, having won the last two matches against the team.With the fansbehind them once again, they will look to repeat last Saturdays triumphant performance as they go against the Aussies for the first time since .As rugby enthusiasts once again fill up the Edinburgh stadium, heres how you can watch at home...Kick-off time for Scotlandv Australia match this weekend The Scotland v Australia match will take place at Murrayfield on Sunday November  at :pm.It is the teams second match in the autumn series, which will take place throughout November.What channel isScotland v Australiaand how to watch live Amazon Prime hasthe broadcast rights for the autumn internationalseries in the UK.You will need a membership to tune in, butyou dont already have one you can sign up to a -day free trial.If you dont want to continue your trial after the -days however, you will need to remember to cancel your subscription.When is Scotlands next match in autumn series Here is Scotlands schedule for the autumn series:Scotland v Australia: Sunday November  at :pmScotland v South Africa: Saturday November  at pmScotland v Japan: Saturday November  at pmWhats the Scotland team line-up Stuart HoggDarcy Graham, Chris Harris, Sam Johnson, Duhan van der Merwe Finn Russell, Ali Price Pierre Schoeman, George Turner, Zander Fagerson, Sam Skinner, Grant Gilchrist, Jamie Ritchie, Hamish Watson, Matt Fagerson.Replacements:Ewan Ashman, Jamie Bhatti, Oli Kebble, Jamie Hodgson, Josh Bayliss, George Horne, Adam Hastings, Kyle Steyn.

title: limmys-show-watch-three-series-limmys-show
story: Limmys Show, the sketch series by Scottish comedian Limmy is available to watch on iPlayer from today.Throughout the show, which has a cult following, Limmy plays himself and a iety of other characters in observational comedy sketches.The first series was broadcast in , with the second and third coming in  and  respectively, airing on BBC Scotland.A Christmas special in  marked the final episode, with Limmy saying he didnt want to do any more episodes in the aftermath.Now all three series are available to watch - heres how you can tune in....Where to watch all three series ofLimmys ShowYou can watch all three series of Limmys Show on BBC iPlayer.The original musicaccompanies the show, rather that the musicwhich was substituted when the show appeared on Netflix.There are  episodes across the three series, plus the Christmas special which is also available on iPlayer.Revealing the news, Limmy tweeted: "I am happy to announce that all three series of Limmys Show are now on iPlayer! Including the pilot! And with the original music, not that stuff I had to swap to for Netflix!"I am happy to announce that all three series of Limmys Show are now on iPlayer!Including the pilot!And with the original music, not that stuff I had to swap to for Netflix!https:t.co RKfyFSyomdash twitch.tv LimmyNovember , The Scottish comedian has a huge following on Twitter where he often posts videos of sketches using the handle @DaftLimmy.His extensive fan base will likely be pleased at the news of the release, with series one and two previously only available on DVD, while series three did not come out on disc.It was available for a short period on Netflix, before being removed in .

title: northern-lights-aurora-borealis-can-see-northern-lights-tonight
story: The northern lights were spotted across the UK last night, from Scotlandall the way down to Devon.It is known officially as an aurora borealis, whichis the latin translation of northern lights.These lights occur when there is activity on the earths sun.Atoms and mollecules from the earths atmosphere collide with particles from the sun and create colours in the sky.The earths magnetic field is what causes the wavy lines and patterns of the northern lights.They are a fairly rare occurence, but we in Scotland might get another chance to see them tonight.Heres what we know...Can I see the northern lights in Scotland tonight According to AuroraWatch UK, parts of Scotland could see the northern lights again tonight.Yesterday, areas across the UK reported sightings of the aurora borealis.As of pm on Thursday, AuroraWatch UK reported "minor geomagnetic activity" on its Facebook page, meaning there is a possibility of an aurora laterthis activity continues.It advised checking the site again when it was dark for confirmation of whether or not the northern lights could be seen in Scotland tonight.The site is available here.The chance of seeing an aurora is on the left side of the graph, while the time is along the bottom of the graph.A red alert means it is likely an aurora will occur, while an amber alert means a possible aurora.Earlier in the day, the site had reported a red alert meaning that an aurora was likely, however this has decreased as the day has gone on.Meanwhile, Met Office space weather expert Krista Hammond also confirmed there was a chance of spotting the lights again tonight."As was predicted by the Met Office Space Weather Operations Centre, a coronal mass ejection impacted with the Earth yesterday."The resulting strong geomagnetic storm meant the Northern Lights were visible across large areas of the UK overnight last night."Wersquove had reports that the aurora could even be seen in some central areas of the UK, which is possible when a storm of this magnitude impacts the Earth..remove"This means there is the potential for further sightings of the Northern Lights overnight, although there will be spells of patchy cloud over Scotland which could limit visibility in places."What time am I most likely to see an aurora The northern lights are usually most visible between pm and am, however they could be spotted any time during the hours of darkness.

title: thought for the week october 15 2021
story: One morning recently, I heard the following two news items on the radio:First was a report about the petrochemical plant at Grangemouth which emits tons of CO into the atmosphere. There are plans to convert it to a hydrogen plant which would capture the CO, send it along a pipeline to Aberdeenshire ready for it to be stored deep under the sea.That was immediately followed by a report on the shortage of CO caused by the increase in energy costs and the closing down of two fertilizer factories which send CO on to other industries, in particular food.How ironic – one industry wants to bury the stuff that others desperately need!I decided to find out more and discovered that CO in ying grades of purity is used in a wide iety of industries.On further research, I also discovered that CO is already being turned from a pollutant into a resource.Companies around the world, including the UK, are reusing CO to make building blocks, cement, foam housing insulation and fuel.I found two examples of companies feeding CO to algae, one to make carbon fibre and the other to revive oyster reefs.#Now it is required that those who have been given a trust must prove faithful.# We are all responsible for the care of our planet, whether as members of faith groups or members of a global society.Refining CO might cost a fortune but not doing so could cost the earth.

title: letters october 22 2021
story: It was great to speak to my constituents in Carradale on my latest visit to the village last Saturday.Many residents mentioned the need to cut the grass verges, especially at junctions, for safety reasons. I have contacted Argyll and Bute Council#s roads management about this on numerous occasions and will continue to do so.I have also been in contact with East Kintyre Community Council about the state of signs at passing places in the area. There are roughly  passing places, some with no signs, some with old and badly deteriorated posts and some with new signs.With the increase in use of many East Kintyre roads, it makes sense to have clearly marked passing places.With more and more people working from home, fit-for-purpose broadband speeds and mobile phone coverage is not just a luxury, but an essential tool for day-to-day le. I have been lobbying BT Openreach and local and national governments for more digital investment in our rural ward.I will continue to work day-in and day-out for our area, making sure voices in Kintyre and the islands are heard.As a clinical nurse specialist on Breast Cancer Now#s helpline, I#m acutely aware of the shattering impact of the Covid- pandemic on the emotional wellbeing of people with breast cancer.News of a diagnosis can be a lonely experience and the pandemic has, at times, exacerbated this, denying people the chance to be with loved ones.We#ve seen a sharp rise in calls to our helpline and emails to our Ask Our Nurses service from people struggling emotionally. Many say the loneliness they#ve felt living with breast cancer during the pandemic has been the hardest emotional impact to cope with and that it has negatively impacted their mental health.As many of us look ahead to a #new normal# beyond the pandemic, we must acknowledge the loneliness legacy facing people who#ve lived with breast cancer through the pandemic and commit to addressing it.This Breast Cancer Awareness Month, we want to remind everyone affected by breast cancer that we#re always with you, in every way we can.Thanks to support from players of People#s Postcode Lottery, our online support services are one click away for anyone after a breast cancer diagnosis.Whether you#re a younger woman, adjusting to le after treatment, or living with incurable secondary breast cancer, our tailored support provides a confidential, safe space to connect with others and access specialist information.Find out more about Younger Women Together, Moving Forward, Someone Like Me, and Living With Secondary Breast Cancer at breastcancernow.org online-services

title: leader october 22 2021
story: It is dficult to understand the Scottish Conservative and Unionist Party#s decision not to allow Donald Kelly to represent the party at the  local election – especially when it will not provide a reason.Councillor Kelly said he met #a wall of silence# when asking for a proper explanation or justication, and the Courier has had a similar experience, with numerous attempts to gain answers proving unsuccessful.We asked why the decision was made and why Councillor Kelly was not made aware or given notice of itit was in relation to his Argyll First membership and why support from former Scottish Conservative leaders Annabel Goldie and Ruth Davidson appeared not to be taken into consideration.If we do receive answers to our questions, we will share them with our readers but until then we can only speculate.Surely Councillor Kelly and the people of South Kintyre deserve to know.Congratulations to Fraser Cursiter and Katie Webster who got engaged this week after Fraser proposed on the beach in Carradale.We wish the couple, who are soon moving to Australia, the best of luck for the future we hope theyto visit the place that has earned a special place in their hearts.

title: thought for the week october 22 2021
story: As we crossed the bridge, we were excited to see the island’s beauty.At first though, we had to take our friend’s word for it, as rain, low cloud and failing light obscured most of it from view. The next day the rain stopped, the clouds lted and the sun broke through.We saw for ourselves that what our friend had said was true. Skye’s scenery is stunning.In John, chapter , verses -, the apostles told Thomas that while he had been away, Jesus had physically appeared to them. Thomas refused to accept as true what they told him, insisting that unless he saw him with his own eyes and touched him with his own hands, he would not believe Jesus was alive.For him, seeing was believing.Later, Jesus once again appeared to the apostles and, this time, Thomas was present. Now Thomas believed. Jesus rebuked him for his unbelief and said: ‘Blessed are those who have not seen yet believe.’We believe lots of things, not because we can see them for ourselves but by accepting the word of those who have.Christians believe in Jesus, not because we have seen him with our own eyes, but because of the reliable word of the apostles who physically saw the risen Jesus with their own eyes.I encourage you to read the Gospels, the accurately written-down eyewitness testimony of the apostles to Jesus so that you might see who he is and as you trust in him alone,

title: cinema prepares of weekend of halloween horrors
story: As part of the national BFI Japan  season, the cinema organised a spooky line-up featuring frightening monster turtles, giant pigs, family anime, whisky tasting, claymation, filmmaking and what is probably the scariest movie of all time.The BFI Japan  entertainment kicked off last Friday, with a screening of Lost in Translation, which was followed by a Japanese whisky-tasting session led by Mark and Kate Watt of Watt Whisky.Tomorrowmorning, children aged between eight and  can get a taste of monster model-making courtesy of Jim Parkyn, lead modelmaker at Aardman Animations, the studio behind Wallace and Gromit and Shaun the Sheep.Jim will help the youngsters create their own monsters, inspired by the likes of Godzilla, the original kaiju – Japanese monster – on film.The children could see their own creations tearing up the Wee Toon as the models will then be used to create a special monster movie which will be screened the following day, on Hallowe#en itself, alongside Gamera: The Giant Monster.Parents are welcome to sit in on the workshop which will last  minutes and will include a chance to ask questions and hear about the master model-maker#s work.The £ workshop ticket includes entry to Gamera: The Giant Monster but spaces are limited and those interested are advised to book as soon as possible.On Saturday afternoon, there will be family anime with Studio Ghibli#s multi-award-winning Spirited Away, considered to be one of the greatest animated films.In the evening, for horror lovers who are brave enough to be scared out of their skins, there#s a rare opportunity to catch the original Ring – Ringu – on the big screen.Ellen Mainwood, Campbeltown Picture House Manager, said: #What more could anyone want of Hallowe#en – giant fire-breathing prehistoric turtle monsters, parents turned into pigs, claymation fun and terrying horror #We#re delighted to be part of the BFI Japan  season, a nationwide celebration of the best of Japanese film.#Tickets for all events, listed below, are on sale now at www.campbeltownpicturehouse

title: from our files october 29 2021
story: Campbeltown#s vital Ring and Ride bus service is safe – for now.It was granted a last-minute reprieve from council budget cuts on Wednesday, two days before it was due to be scrapped.Argyll and Bute Council agreed to continue the Ring and Ride service whilst it takes time to look for an alternative.Councillor Rory Colville, community spokesman for Argyll and Bute Council, said: #We are responding to the concerns of the people who need this service most.#It will continue in its current form for as long as it takes to make an informed decision about changes and we will make people aware of what will be provided in the future.#No timescale was given as to whether this would be before next May#s elections.In last year#s budget, the service was earmarked for the axe at the time, but the council gave assurances alternative arrangements would be put in place.Councillor John Semple said: #I am glad to see that finally some common sense seems to be filtering through – only three weeks ago the administration voted to continue with this cut.#I will continue to look after the interests of the most vulnerable people in this community as the administration#s plans materialise.#Argyll First councillor Donald Kelly was a prime mover in establishing and expanding the service and is totally against the withdrawal.He told the Courier that this is only a stay of execution for this service and assurances are needed that the service will be retained in the long-term.TWENTY-FIVE YEARS AGOThe MP for Argyll and Bute has pressed for additional facts about the ferry service between Campbeltown and Ballycastle.During last Friday#s Scottish Questions in the House of Commons, Mrs Ray Michie pressed the Secretary of State for Scotland, Mr Michael Forsyth, for more information.She said: #I welcome the announcement, at long last, of the ferry service, although I am disappointed Caledonian MacBrayne was not allowed to run it.#She went on to ask: #For how long does Sea Containers have the contract  Is the Secretary of State expecting the service eventually to run all year, so that we can build up not only a good tourist service, but a good import and export trade #Mr Forsyth responded: #It was important for the new route to be established. It was possible to achieve that with a private sector operator taking the risk, which means that CalMac#s available public capital and running costs can be deployed on maintaining other services and introducing new ones.#It must be the right approach to use the state#s nationalised service and the scarce resources available to it as wisely as possible.#That was what lay behind our thinking.#He went on to say that he would write to Mrs Michie regarding the contract.Mrs Michie commented: #It is important we get the full facts about this service so that we can judge whether this really is value for money as the government claims.#FIFTY YEARS AGOEmergency sea rescue services in the Firth of Clyde could have been victims of another hoax on Friday.For the Campbeltown leboat, three naval vessels and a Dakota aircraft spent nearly six hours searching Kilbrannan Sound and its approaches for a boat reported to have been sinking off Campbeltown.The drama began at lunchtime when the Campbeltown leboat mechanic, Mr Alistair Gilchrist, intercepted a wireless message which read: #Mayday Boy Danny sinking  degrees off Campbeltown.#Kildonan Coastguard Station, Troon Leboat Station and Portpatrick Radio also picked up the call the boat#s name, however, was not mentioned in the message received by the other three stations.Then a full-scale search operation swung into operation. Along with the leboat, the warship HMS Eastbourne, Fishery Protection vessel Vigilant and the US Navy ship Victoria began combing the area between the south of Arran and Kintyre.They were joined later in the search by a Dakota aircraft from Prestwick.An RAF patrol vessel stood by at Campbeltown.Campbeltown leboat reported the discovery of a large piece of timber. It was, however, too heavy to lt aboard and it was not thought to be part of possible wreckage.Then, after six hours, the search was called off. The plane and boats had covered an extensive area of sea.Coastguards using mobile equipment searched along the shores of Arran and Kintyre.Nothing was seen.Police in Campbeltown began investigations into the matter shortly after the leboat put to sea their enquiries are continuing.ONE HUNDRED YEARS AGOAuchencorvie United, one of the teams that came into being in the rural area as a result of the formation of sports clubs among agricultural workers, made their first appearance in local competitive football last Saturday afternoon.Drumlemble supplied the opposition and had a comparatively easy victory by four goals to nil.Auchencorvie had several players of some promise but, as a whole, the team was sadly wanting in science and judgement and the lesson of their first experience should impress on them the fact that mere lusty vigour is not sufficient to win on the football field.In the first half, Drumlemble did not press their undoubted superiority unduly, being content with a one-goal lead at the interval.
